title: brexit theresa may house of commons jacob rees mogg
story: The top Brexiteer insisted the PM would have to consider asking the Queen to prorogue Parliament rather than accept a bid to take No Deal off the table.Critics accused Mr Rees-Mogg of launching a coup by trying to take away the right of MPs to pass laws.Speaking to the Bruges Group think-tank in London, the European Research Group boss hit out at a amendment tabled by Yvette Cooper.The motion, due to be voted on next week, would give MPs the power to delay BrexitBritain is headed for No Deal.Mr Rees-Mogg said: “They are trying to thwart what they themselves voted for. This would be a constitutional outrage.The proper, settled arrangements between the executive and legislature have worked well for centuries.If the House of Commons undermines our basic constitutional conventions then the executive is entitled to use other vestigial constitutional means to stop it. By which I basically mean prorogation.I hope it would not be necessary for the Queen’s stay at Sandringham to be interrupted for her in person to prorogue Parliament.We do not want that sort of constitutional crisis, we want to observe the constitutional norms.The Brexiteer again hinted that he could carry out a U-turn and back Mrs Mays dealshe ditches the hated Irish backstop plan.He said: There are outbreaks of realism all around I see.I’m sure common sense and practicality will now prevail. The backstop doesn’t work for unionists in the Tory party, or the DUP.The pretence that we might ever swallow it is now over. It’s long past time to get on and just do the feasible deal that has always been there to do.”But he denied becoming a soft touch, insisting: “As long as the backstop is there, I will not vote for this deal.Tory MP Nick Boles, who has sponsored the anti-No Deal amendment, accused him of a coup, adding: The only people blocking Brexit are those like Jacob Rees-Mogg who voted against a Brexit deal last week.A No source told The Sun that officials have already discussed the idea of proroguing Parliament - but quickly dismissed it.The source said: Its at the least plausible end of about  options weve talked about.A number of Brexiteers are worried thatthey dont end up backing the PMs deal, Remainers will succeed in keeping Britain in the EU.Today Ben Bradley told the BBC: I do feel and having spoken to colleagues in the DUP, and Brexiteer colleagues, thatshe gets that movement on the backstop she will get a majority.But EU envoy Michel Barnier said preparing for No Deal is now more important than ever.He urged MPs to decide what they want to happen, saying: To stop No Deal, a positive majority for another solution will need to emerge.It would be welcomed by big business - but Brexit voters would be unhappy because it would mean Britain accepting open borders, and following European rules without a say.HOW LIKELY   HARD AS NAILSMost of the Tory Brexiteers who oppose the PMs deal want her toto Brussels and strike a tougher line.But Eurocrats currently insist its impossible to re-open negotiations.HOW LIKELY   REFERENDUM RE-RUNDozens of MPs are hell-bent on forcing Mrs May to hold a second referendum so Britain can stay in the EU.Yet without the support of the Government its unlikely the second vote could become a reality.HOW LIKELY   DEAL OR NO DEAL If Mrs May cannot pass a deal, the legal default is that we will leave the EU without a deal on March .Despite the legal position, the majority of MPs insist they will take any measure necessary to rule out No Deal.HOW LIKELY   MAY TRIUMPHS - EVENTUALLYCabinet ministers remain adamant that a version of Theresa Mays plan will eventually pass the Commons, even after losing last week.They believe sceptical MPs will lose their nerve as Brexit Day approaches - terried of either No Deal or a second referendum.HOW LIKELY   We have to give this brief period of time to the UK Parliament, to the UK Government, to have this debate and to take their decision.A new poll provided hope for Mrs May, suggesting that her deal is the most acceptable outcome for most Brits.Nearly half of voters said they could accept the deal, with only  per cent disagreeing, according to Number Cruncher Politics.But Boris Johnson appeared to strike a softer approach as he signalled he could back the dealthe PM secured the power to quit the backstop unilaterally.No is hoping the threat of the so-called ‘Cooper-Boles amendment will persuade Brexit rebels to back the PM’s deal.Leading Cabinet Brexiteer Liam Fox warned Tory rebels that the Remainer amendment was a “real danger” to Brexit because “what they really mean is not having Brexit at all”.He urged Tory MPs to “swallow” their pride and back the PM’s deal or risk losing Brexit altogether.The chances of the ‘Cooper-Boles’ amendment succeeding were given a major boost last night after Jeremy Corbyn was preparing to formally back it.Sources said Yvette Cooper had agreed to shorten the ‘delay’ to Brexit from nine months to three months in a bid to win more support from Labour and Tory backbenchers.The amendment to Mrs May’s Plan B is expected to be voted on next Tuesday. The plan calls on the PM to agree a deal by February  or extend Article  – effectively ruling out a No Deal.Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd warned No. last week that dozens of Ministers want to back it.Hardcore Remainer Lord Adonis said Mr Rees-Mogg’s plan was “appallingly reactionary” and pointed out that the last time a monarch vetoed a bill was Queen Anne in .A string of British business leaders including the bosses of JML and Wetherspoon, penned a letter to the Prime Minister urging her to pursue a managed No Deal Brexit.The letter said: “The Government’s deal is not in the best interests of business, nor is it the only option. The Government has tried to portray Theresa May’s deal as the only one that delivers for business that is simply not true.“As businesses, we do not fear a managed No Deal but welcome it. title: annegret kramp karrenbauer irish backstop
story: Unlikely because it does not yet exist and requires a sharp change of attitude on all sides.But in times of crisis, ­anything is possible.Hardline Tory Brexiteers are now prepared to vote for ­Theresa May’s shattered EU Withdrawal Bill — as long as she ditches the wretched Northern Ireland backstop.Meanwhile, Germany is under siege from its political and industrial leaders, who are finally speaking out against a breach in trade and security ties with a vital European ally.Together this makes it ­possible to navigate a way through the thicket of bitterness and rancour which has soured ­politics, ided families and split the British nation.It requires a change of tack from Theresa May — never an easy ask.The PM’s deal is toxic because it hands Northern ­Ireland to Brussels as a ­province of the EU.Cutting out this tumour would win Mrs May the backing of at least  MPs, including Tory Brexiteers and the hardline DUP.Remainers would have ­little choice but to join in, giving Mrs May her majority and scuppering Jeremy ­Corbyn’s demands for a snap election.This might be seen as an impossible dream, not least because the hated backstop was allegedly invented in Downing Street, not Brussels.German negotiators pounced on an easy win.Now Berlin, the ultimate EU power broker, is facing fierce protests from industrialists over the risk to car, aerospace and engineering giantsBritain leaves with No Deal.“A hard Brexit would be disastrous,” says Dieter Kempf, head of Germany’s BDI — the equivalent of our Confederation of British Industry.“It would cause great dficulty for tens of thousands of companies and hundreds of thousands of workers on both sides.”Friday’s touching note from German politicians to The Times newspaper pleads with Britain to stay — or at least leave on friendly terms.But this is no love letter. It is hard-nosed realism.Signicantly, it bears the ­signature of Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, Angela Merkel’s chosen successor as Germany’s next Chancellor.Her appeal can be seen as a rebuke to Mrs Merkel, who rejected David Cameron’s plea for help to curb immigration, tipping ­Britain towards Brexit.Brits might have chosen dferentlyshe had responded to voters’ dismay not just in Britain but across the EU.She later signed her own political death warrant by flinging open Europe’s borders to a million Syrian migrants.But voters’ resentment towards arrogant EU leaders — recorded by their own Eurostat polling system — long predates immigration.Embattled French President Emmanuel Macron recently admitted he had dared not offer his voters a “Frexit”  ­referendum — because they would leave in a flash.Weeks later, his fears were confirmed as “yellow-vest” anarchists set Paris ablaze.French observers believe the gilets jaunes riots have their origins in another referendum crisis.In , France voted overwhelmingly against the European Constitution — only to see it renamed the Lisbon Treaty and slyly introduced against their express wishes.The European Constitution, like the disastrous euro, was a crucial but unpopular step towards a federal European superstate.Ireland and ­Denmark have also voted down EU moves to ever-closer union.They were told to vote again until they said Yes.Brussels’ arrogant contempt for ordinary voters — dismissed by one French president as “scum” — is what politicians blithely describe as the “democratic deficit”.It sowed the seeds for Brexit. Immigration simply brought it to a head.Germany’s letter to The Times reads like a plea from a deserted lover.“Without your great nation, this continent would not be what it is today — a community defined by freedom and ­prosperity,” writes Germany’s next Chancellor.“Should Britain wish to leave the European Union for good, it will always have friends in Germany and Europe.”This is precisely what British voters hoped for as they ­teetered on the brink of Remain but opted to Leave.They wanted a civilised orce between economic and diplomatic allies.This is still possiblethe border issue can be resolved.If we can persuade the IRA to decommission deadly weapons, surely we can decommission a backstop that nobody wants Theresa May’s rejected deal is not a total failure. Without this problem it could still fly.Germany holds the key.If Mrs Kramp-Karrenbauer means what she said about friendship, now is the time to prove it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit michel barnier crushes key
story: NewsBrexit: Michel Barnier crushes key plan B allies hoped could save Theresa MayThe EU has repeatedly ruled out putting an expiry date on the backstopShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMichel Barnier has crushed a key plan B allies of Theresa May had hoped could have led to a breakthrough on her rejected Brexit deal.The EU has repeatedly ruled out putting an expiry date on the backstop - an insurance policy to keep an open border on the island of Ireland in the event of no deal.The EUs Chief Negotiator said that calls for a time-limit had been repeatedly discussed and rejected by the EU.Mr Barnier said in a joint interview to European newspapers “we cannot tie the backstop to a time limit”. Government loyalist Andrew Murrison tabled an amendment to Theresa Mays Withdrawal Bill to set an expiry date on the Northern Ireland backstop.   The amendment was not chosen by the Speaker and the PMs deal was rejected by  votes.On Monday Theresa May ed to the Commons to put forward her plan B - which involves minor tweaks to her first plan.MPs are now putting forward amendments to try and seize control of the process.Mr Murrison believes his amendment, which imposes a time-limit on the backstop, could help Mrs May get her deal through the Commons by appealing to moderate MPs who just want Brexit sorted. But Mr Barnier has insisted there can be no time limit on the backstop.He told them: The backstop is like an insurance. It is not there to be used. Andso, only provisionally. However, we cannot tie the backstop to a time limit.   Asked why not, he told journalists: Imagineyour home’s insurance was limited to five years and you’d have a problem after six years... Thats dficult to justy, he replied. Its similar with the backstop. That is why it is tied to an event: as soon as there is an agreement between the EU and the UK that makes an internal border unnecessary, it will be obsolete. Let me remind you that we have negotiated the elements of the backstop with the British government and have integrated their wishes into it. On Tuesday the EU insisted that a no deal Brexit would mean a hard border on the island of Ireland.At a press conference the chief spokesman for European commission president Jean-Claude Juncker, said it was “pretty obvious” border infrastructure would be necessarythere was no agreement.   But on Wednesday they backtracked. The same spokesman said: The EU is determined to do all it can - deal or no deal- to avoid a hard border in Ireland. Meanwhile the chief commissioner of the Irish Human Rights and Equality Commissionsaid the Withdrawal Agreement reached between the UK and the EU left signicant gaps in the protection of human rights. Emily Logan said: I dont think the public understand that the implications... people might find themselves in a situation of being forced to assume an identy they wouldnt choose. Ms Logan said the offer of continued EU citizenship should be extended to all the people of NorthernIreland as defined by the Good Friday Agreement, given recognition of the birthright of people in NorthernIrelandto identy as Irish or British, or both. The last situation we wish to see is one where the people of NorthernIrelandfeel forced to choose their identity based on what they think their post-Brexit entitlements might be, she said.

Some , tonnes of steel worth pound.million was supplied from Belgium for a Royal Navy Astute-class hunter-killer submarine. And pound.million of steel - , tonnes - including some from Sweden, was bought for Royal Navy Type  frigates. The MoD said “Not all of the required specications for Type  steel are manufactured in the UK. Thin plate steel is sourced from overseas .” For the Astute sub, it added: “This grade of steel is only available from France, due to its specialist nature.”  However, British firms have repeatedly insisted thatthey are given enough time, they could produce specialist products. Network Rail bought , tonns of steel, mainly from Austria and Spain, for two “niche projects”, together worth almost pound,million. It claimed “technical specications” were required. But Mr Doughty added: “Whether it’s roads, rail or our national defence the Tory Government is letting down the nation and betraying our steelworkers by a failure to buy British.”  Paul McBean, , a steelworker at Scunthorpe for  years, said: “We’ve had a rough few years in the industry, and steelworkers have all done their bit to help keep things afloat. “Government ministers keep saying they support British steel making, but they’ve got to put their money where their mouth it. “Publishing this information is helpful, butthey’re serious about helping our industry survive and thrive then the Government will have to do an awful lot better when it comes to buying British steel.” The figures were set out in a -page document called ‘Steel Public Procurement: Compliance with the steel procurement guidance’ published by the Department for business, Energy and Industrial Strategy. Community steelworkers’ union general secretary Roy Rickhuss said: “Getting procurement policy right is crucial to developing an industrial strategy that supports UK steelmaking, and government should be leading the way.  “British steelworkers are the best in the world but we’ve always said we need to make public procurement policy work for our home industries just like they do in other countries.” The “data means we can hold government to account”, he said, adding: “There is much room for improvement.” Labour MP Stephen Kinnock accused the Government of “failing to lend support” to the fragile British steel sector. Mr Kinnock, whose constituency includes Britain’s biggest steelworks, Port Talbot, said: “The steel industry is the industrial backbone of the United Kingdom.  Mr Kinnock added: “It’s a huge betrayal to steel communities like mine in Aberavon that the UK Government are procuring less than % of their steel from British steelworks. “The fact is that this is a betrayal of British steelworkers and of their families and communities. “These decisions are made in Westminster and the Government should be putting its money where its mouth is. “There is, of course, an alternative. The Labour Party’s Build it in Britain campaign will use a mix of public procurement and a new National Investment Bank to boost manufacturing across the country, contrasting greatly with the Tories’ abject failure to back British business.” UK Steel director Gareth Stace welcomed “important and positive steps” from the Government, including publishing the data.

story: NewsMan wins seat for le in Parliament thanks to his ancestor becoming a Lord in Aeneas Simon Mackay, a Tory investment banker, can now vote on your laws and claim £ a day for leShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAeneas Simon Mackay, a Tory investment banker, can now vote on your laws and claim £ a day for le "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man has joined the House of Lords for le after an election he could only enter because his great-grandads cousins dads fourth cousins dads cousins great-great-great-grandad was made a Lord in . Tory investment banker Aeneas Simon Mackay, the th Lord Reay, can now vote on your laws and claim pound a day after triumphing in a hereditary peer by-election - a system branded a mockery of our democracy. The -year-old is the chief of ancient Scottish Clan Mackay, whose former leader Donald Mackay was handed a peerage by Charles I. According to the Clan Mackay Society, folklore describes Lord Reay as a magician who won a work-loving gang of fairies in an encounter with a witch in a cave.His coat of arms is said to be two daggers pointed at a roebucks head surrounded by the heads of three muzzle-wearing bears.   But the th Lords existence has been a bit less mystical. He went to pound,-a-year Westminster School before founding a corporate finance advisory boutique and working in New York. His father, the th Lord, sat in the Lords for almost  years and campaigned against onshore wind farms before his death in . According to Cracrofts Peerage, Donald Mackay was the current Lords great-grandads cousins dads fourth cousins dads cousins great-great-great-grandad. Darren Hughes, chief executive of the Electoral Reform Society, said: While MPs debate what taking back control really means, Lords have picked yet another aristocrat to vote on our laws for le. With just -odd votes from Britains feudal few, this man will now be able to claim pound a day plus travel costs to steer our politics.  Labour leader in the Lords Baroness Smith added: As much as we welcome an inidual Lord, the system has had its day. It is increasingly dficult to defend - a temporary measure that has gone on beyond its time. Todays election result was a hangover from Tony Blairs bid to modernise the House of Lords. Hereditary peers were mostly cast out in  but  remained as a compromise. That means when one dies or retires, there is an election to find their replacement. But only hereditary peers can stand in that election, and only members of the House of Lords can vote. The latest election was held to replace Tory Lord Skelmersdale, an Old Etonian who sat in the Lords for  years before his death in October.  All  candidates were men including  Conservatives, five independent crossbenchers and one unaffiliated. In total  peers voted and Lord Reay won with  votes, beating the second-placed Earl of Leicester who won . The Earl of Carnarvon, who lives in the real-le home that stages Downton Abbey, won just  votes. In his manesto, Lord Reay told peers: My career expertise derives from  years in the financial services sector in London and New York, at investment banks and boutique corporate firms , with a focus on advising UK and international businesses. I am a board member of three technology companies. Based predominantly in London and partially in rural Lancashire, I will be able to devote as much time to the House as required.has attempted to contact the peer for comment on his victory and criticism of the system.

story: News things that make British people feel rubbish - how many are you dealing with One in three go for months without a day feeling fit and wellShareCommentsByGemma Francis:,  JAN NewsA bad or busy day at work is one of the most common reasons for feeling lousy "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe average Brit only feels ‘fit as a fiddle’ nine times a month, a study has found. Tiredness, heavy workloads and a lack of exercise mean less than one third of the year is spent feeling in tip top condition, both mentally and physically. Instead, the average adult will have three days a week where they feel tired or lacking in energy, and two occasions where they spend the day in a bad mood. More than one third of adults even have whole months go by where they don’t have a single day of feeling on top form.   The study by Vitabiotics’ Wellwoman and Wellman vitamin range also found January is the month most likely to see Brits struggling. A spokesman said: “At this time of year, it can be rare to have a day where you feel wide awake, in a great mood and ready for whatever le throws at you. “But it’s staggering to see just how few days we have where we feel great. “Simply feeling a little bit tired, or overloaded at work, can leave us feeling out of sorts – it really doesn’t take much to take our day from perfect to just so-so.   “Sometimes, just making small lestyle changes, like improving your diet or doing a little bit of exercise, can make a huge dference to how you feel, hopefully boosting the time you spend feeling on top form.” The study also found  per cent of Brits admit they are more likely to have days where they feel tired or be in a bad mood than feel completely perfect. And  per cent say it’s rare for them to wake up and feel like they are raring to go as soon as they get out of bed. In fact, the average adult has less than four hours a day where they feel full of energy.   A bad night’s sleep is most likely to leave Brits feeling anything less than tip top, along with stress, going to bed too late and having an early wake up call. A bad or busy day at work, a poor diet and an argument with someone are also among the most common reasons for having days where they feel a little lousy. Worryingly,  per cent even said they have fallen out with someone as a result of not feeling completely perfect, with many respondents admitting to being snappier than usual when they are tired. Researchers also found  per cent of those polled, via OnePoll, have pulled a sickie at work because they didn’t feel in the mood to go in, and almost one in five have pretended to have an appointment to get out of having to go in first thing.   More than half have even cancelled a night out with friends because they didn’t feel up to it and  per cent have pulled out of a date. A spokesman for Vitabiotics Wellman and Wellwoman added: “It is worrying that so few Brits feel genuinely in tip-top physical condition and it goes to show how important a good diet and plenty of sleep is for the demands of today’s modern lestyle. For those wanting to stay on top, Wellman and Wellwoman provides micronutrient support with over  vitamins and minerals, plus more. “If you are having one of those days, Wellman and Wellwoman Energy is the ideal addition to tablets when you want an extra boost of energy releasing vitamins. Both make a great tasting refreshing drink with vitamins B and B, magnesium and iron which contribute to normal energy release and the reduction of tiredness and fatigue.” Top  things which cause Brits to feel less than tip top:A bad night’s sleep Stress Going to bed late the night before Having to wake up early A bad day at work A bad diet An argument with their partner Not getting in their usual amount of exercise A hefty workload Drinking too much

story: NewsBurglar claimed he moved into home after popstar Cheryl donated it to himAndrew Coates, , appeared on several hours of CCTV footage with a rucksack and sleeping bag inside the Devon home of Alison Piper, a jury heardShareByStuart AbelAbigail OLeary:,  JAN NewsAppearing at Plymouth Crown Court, Coates denied burgling the property in March last year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn alleged burglar caught inside a house claimed he had moved into the property after it was donated to him by popstar Cheryl, a court heard. Andrew Coates, , appeared on several hours of CCTV footage with a rucksack and sleeping bag inside the Devon home of Alison Piper, a jury heard. When questioned by police, Coates said the former Girls Aloud singer and X Factor judge had gted him the home after buying it for pound.m the day before. It is alleged that Coates stole several valuable items from the house, including a Rolex watch worth more than pound,. Appearing at Plymouth Crown Court, Coates denied burgling the property in March last year, alongside one charge of criminal damage and three theft charges. Alison Piper, the home’s true owner, told the trial that she had not sold the house to the celebrity, whose maiden name is Cheryl Tweedy.  Adrian Chaplin, opening the case for the Crown Prosecution Service, said Coates was arrested after the residents ed to their home in the morning. He said: “Mr Coates said that he had been given the house, which had been bought the previous day by Cheryl Tweedy. He had been given it by her during a conversation.” Mr Chaplin added that Coates had later been diagnosed by psychiatrists as suffering from delusional disorder. The barrister said that the defendant believed that everything in the house were “gts” for him from the former X Factor judge. Mr Chaplin told the jury that Coates appeared on several hours of CCTV footage from the couple’s home security cameras after arriving at .pm. The barrister continued that he was carrying a rucksack and a sleeping bag. Coates allegedly stole the home owners Rolex Yacht Master, Apple Watch and ious keys.  He added he was spotted in a detached garage inside a white Ferrari and appeared to be looking for the keys. Mr Chaplin said that Coates was later picked up inside the home in just a shirt and boxer shorts. He added that the defendant took a shower but left the water running and flooded the bathroom, causing damage to the furnishings. Mrs Piper told the jury that she ed home moments before her husband in separate cars at am the next morning. She added that she asked the defendant who he was but he replied by asking her the same question. She said: “He made me feel very uncomfortable ashe resented my presence there. He made me feel asI was intruding. “He took a step towards me and he stared at me very aggressively and assertively.” Barry White, for Coates, asked her what she thought of the suggestion that she had sold the house to Cheryl Tweedy. Mrs Piper said: “No, I did not.” The trial continues.

story: NewsMan in catch- as only chance transplant unavailable due to mystery diseaseCarl McConville, , was diagnosed with lung disease at the age of  - but doctors are still unable to identy what type of the disease the young man suffers fromShareCommentsByAbigail OLearyKatie Dickinson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsCarl McConville is unable to add his name to the transplant waiting list"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old is stuck in a desperate catch- after being told his only chance of survival is a transplant - but he is unable to go on the waiting list due to his mystery lung disease. Carl McConville, from Newcastle, was diagnosed with lung disease at the age of , with doctors telling his mum Lyn he may only live to see one more Christmas. But, Lyn, , said her little fighter of a son defied all the odds to reach his st birthday. Carls condition is now dramatically deteriorating and a lung transplant could save his le, reports Chronicle Live. But mum Lyn says NHS Blood and Transplant have been unable to put him on the list while the type of lung disease he has remains a mystery. Now his family are determined to make the most of their time with Carl and grant his final two wishes - to go on a cruise and to take Carl to an away match to watch his beloved Newcastle United.   Speaking about Carls diagnosis as a child, Lyn described how the original signs something was wrong was his persistent cough. She said: It was more in winter than in summer, he would just have this cough. He got put on steroids at one point which helped him at the time, but then it started all over again. Carl was checked for asthma at , which was when doctors discovered he had a far more serious lung condition. Lyn said: It was around Christmas time we found out. We cant forget that day - December .   They said take him home and enjoy Christmas because we dont know how long hes got left to live. Initially we were told he wouldnt make it to his th birthday without a transplant. But hes just turned  - I call him my little fighter. Lyn says the type of disease is still a mystery, and Carl is the only person in the world with his particular condition. She said: Hes just not breathing properly and hes now had to go on -hour oxygen. Hes been in hospital now for just over a week.   His doctor says he needs a double lung transplant but he cant go on the list yet because we dont know what disease hes got or why hes got it. Its just a catch- at the minute, we cant do anything. Its infuriating but Carls doing okay - he always just gets on with it. Family friend Emma Stockman-Brown has started to fundraise to make Carls two wishes come true. Emma said: When he got put on oxygen I thought the time was right to go ahead with it and let him do what he wants to do.   He wants to go on a cruise but with his condition we dont know how far theyll let him travel, so we were thinking just a little cruise to Paris or something - I think he wants to go on the boat more than anything. And he wants to go to see Newcastle United play away - he goes to see them all the time but hes not been to an away match. Emma is hoping to organise a fundraising event in April or May for Carl, and has set up an online crowdfunding page in the meantime. To help with the appeal visit the JustGiving page here .

An old friend of mine did a double take the other day when I said hi as she didnt notice it was me at all. My whole outlook on le is dferent. Before all I did was sit about on the sofa and order takeaways whereas now Im super active and have tonnes of energy all the time.  Kelleywas a size  before having Kylo, now three, but after he was born she developed unhealthy eating habits. She typically had white toast for breakfast, followed by sandwich and crisps for lunch, a takeaway for dinner, while snacking on more crisps, fizzy drinks and chocolate. She piled on eight stone, but soon got fed up, and when she got desperate she tried diet pills. They were dreadful, I had no energy and couldnt stop pooing the whole time, she admitted. It was around this time that her fitness fanatic fianceacute, Ryan Lake, stepped in to help. She said: Ryan was amazing, he could see how depressed I was and just gently took control but by coaxing me to the gym. Id never have had the confidence to do it without him. At first I found it so hard, I wanted to give up, I really hated it but I kept at it and with the changes in my diet too I found that I was actually losing weight! She also started eating ready meals, which were typically between  and  calories a meal. Her favourites were Morrison’s Chicken Tikka Masala, Beef Hot Pots or Macaroni, and she started eating Weetabix and fruit for breakfast, with wraps for lunch. The new mum stopped snacking between meals and started swapping sweet drinks for water.  In the first three months of her new regime she lost a whopping three stone. In a year Kelley had lost NINE stone. She admitted: Im such a gym bunny now its unreal I go whenever I have a second and absolutely love it. Dedicated Kelley, who is also mother to -year-old Tamzin, has noticed far more than just weight loss benefits from her new regime. Her knees are no longer a problem and her down days are well behind her. The mum-of-two said: I was quite low before as I felt so under-confident but these days I really do feel like a new person. title: mum rushes new york see
story: NewsMum rushes to New York to see dying son, , but arrives too late for final goodbyeShaun Dobinson, , told his mum "I love you" before he died of complications due to untreated diabetesShareCommentsByHannah GrahamNeil Murphy:,  JAN NewsShaum, , failed to get adequate medical attention "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum took a flight to New York as her son lay dying - only to discover he had tragically passed away before she could get to his side. Shaun Dobinson, , died of complications due to untreated diabetes, an inquest heard. The electrical engineer had been looking forward to a trip to New York with his childhood pal, Matthew Folley.The pair had been planning to do some sightseeing after arriving in the city on May , , senior coroner Derek Winter said. But Shauns condition took a dramatic turn for the worse after he began vomiting in his room and telling his mum Julie he was scared for his le, Chronicle Live reported. Sunderland Coroners Court heard how GP Dr Nadu Bhatt had discovered Shaun was diabetic on May , and on May  had referred him for an urgent specialist appointment.   Dr Bhatt denied knowing Shaun planned to travel to New York but Shauns sister, Kirsty Dobinson, claimed the doctor had been told of the trip but hadnt warned Shaun not to go. He should have been seen within two weeks of his diagnosis but instead was offered an appointment on June  - a date which his doctor agreed was unacceptable. An expert said Shaun needed to receive formal diagnosis and start insulin treatment quickly.  But Dobson left for the US without specialist assessment and a vital prescription for metformin - used to treat Type  diabetes. Mr Folley gave emotional evidence as to how his best friends health had deteriorated during the trip and how Shaun had made light of his new diabetes diagnosis. Matthew said: I think he didnt know how serious it could be. He was worried it would harm his chances of getting into the RAF in the long-term, but at the time he just kept making a joke of it. Matthew noted how Shaun started drinking a lot of water and then began to feel more and more ill.   On Monday, May , the pair visited the Chrysler Building, but by the Tuesday, Shaun was vomiting in his room, the inquest heard. On the Tuesday night, a doctor was called to the pairs Manhattan hotel. The US doctor - who has not yet been identied - told Shaun he was suffering from dehydration and suggested he take over-the-counter medication. In a statement read by the coroner, Ms Dobinson told how Shaun had called his mum at am on the Tuesday, telling her he was scared and wanted to come home.  He later sent her a message saying I love you and miss you so much. In a WhatsApp call on Thursday, June , Ms Dobinson said Shaun had seemed disorientated and had dficulty speaking. And the next time Julie called, the phone was answered by a police officer - who told her emergency services had arrived and were taking Shaun urgently to hospital. She said: I had arranged a flight to New York on Friday at am.Just prior to the flight I received a call to tell me that Shaun had taken a turn for the worse. I askedthey could keep him alive until I could see him. On arrival I was brought to the front of the plane, and informed that Shaun had passed away. The inquest is expected to conclude on Thursday.

title: mum two cleared just 20
story: NewsMum-of-two cleared in just  MINUTES after being taken to court for fly-tippingLauren Pinhorne, , was taken to court by Test Valley Borough Council after flowers addressed to her and an old diary were found among dumped rubbishShareCommentsByElaine McCahillAssistant News Editor:,  JAN NewsLauren Pinhorne was taken to court by a council after flowers addressed to her were found among dumped rubbish "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-two who was taken to court for fly tipping has been cleared in just  minutes. Lauren Pinhorne was confronted by investigators after flowers addressed to her were found among dumped rubbish. Officials claimed she had tossed a plastic bag containing the flowers and an old diary down at the side of a road. The -year-old vehemently protested her innocence but Test Valley Borough Council instigated an  month legal process. However, it took jurors at Winchester Crown Court just  minutes to clear Mrs Pinhorne of fly tipping after a day and a half long trial.   Mrs Pinhorne, who was granted legal aid for the case, said the council had spent at least pound, taking her to court, adding she hoped they would learn a lesson and stop wasting taxpayers money. But a spokeswoman for the council claimed they had carried out a thorough investigation, adding it is important to prosecute people they believe have been fly tipping. Winchester Crown Court, Hants, heard a bag containing flowers addressed to Mrs Pinhorne and an old  diary of hers were found on February , last year. Mrs Pinhorne said she believed the flowers could have been a Valentines Day gt from a former boyfriend, while the diary had gone missing from her home months earlier. Despite telling investigators she knew nothing about the dumping of either of the items in Andover, Hants, they refused to believe her.   Speaking after the court case, she said: I knew I had not done this, I clearly told them I had lost the diary but I was threatened with being arrested. Everything I have said has been true, so I brought it to crown court because it felt like I was being set up. None of the rubbish there was mine, I hadnt dumped it, and they went for me anyway. I have been spoken to really rudely, I actually had to request one of the investigators stop contacting me because of they way he spoke to me. Because they found my old diary, my personal le has been dragged through the court as well - diary entries about personal things were read out. That diary, which had my name inside it, went missing from my home months before it was found. The flowers they found with the diary were in a yellow carrier bag and there was an envelope with my name on in there as well.  They must have been a Valentines Day present, possibly from a former boyfriend, but I never received them. I am very pleased to have won, but the council have just spent at least pound, on the cost of bringing this case. They will now have to pay my costs as well so I would estimate it could go up to pound, - thats taxpayers money. I hope the council learns a lesson from this, this was a waste of taxpayers money. Mrs Pinhorne, of Picket Piece near Andover, denied one count of fly tipping. A spokeswoman for Test Valley Borough Council said: We took this to court following a thorough and comprehensive investigation and external counsel advice confirming that there was a case to answer. Although we are naturally disappointed with the result we, of course, respect the courts decision.  We are extremely proud of our record in tackling fly-tipping having been successful in securing a prosecution in  out of  cases since the start of . The cost to the taxpayer of clearing up fly-tips and impact on communities is signicant. That is why it is important the council continues to seek to prosecute those we believe have fly-tipped in order to discourage people from illegally dumping their waste in our beautul borough.

title: terrifying catalogue knives seized london
story: NewsTerrying catalogue of all the knives seized from capitals streets THIS yearImages lay bare the sheer number of knives taken off the streets by Scotland Yard officers in just a fortnightShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsPolice in Bromley, southeast London, seized a terrying weapon recently "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChilling photos lay bare the sheer number of knives police have taken off the capitals streets already this year. It has tweeted almost  pictures of the confiscated knives, used in robberies, left in bushes and gathered in stop and searches. Last year was one of the worst in recent years for murders in London. Figures show the number of people killed hit a -year high with more than a fth of victims teenagers or children. The  homicides recorded by the politan Police included  where the victims were aged  or under. Of those,  were stabbed, five were shot and one woman was killed by a head injury. It was London’s highest homicide total since , which saw  people killed, and a  per cent rise year-on-year. politan Police Commissioner Cressida Dick had recently named street violence as her number one priority and acknowledged that  was challenging.  Kne crime campaigners have welcomed the ongoing work to remove weapons and praised police for putting the images on their Twitter accounts. Patrick Green, of the charity Ben Kinsella Trust, said: It’s really important to take knives off the streets. Some of the work the politan Police have been doing extends beyond stop and search - we know that they are now doing sweeps of parks and public areas. That’s really an important piece of work for us because we know that habitual kne carriers who are fearful of being stopped will place knives in locations so they can go to that location and retrieve them so the work being done by the police there is really welcomed. We have also seen that they are doing a lot of those searches in conjunction with members of the public or community groups so there is a sense of helping other members of the community support to them in their work.  That’s good because local people have a lot of intelligence about where things might be hidden. Targeted use of stop and search done in an intelligence led way we are happy with - it’s an important police tactic. We are really pleased to see the police take a proactive stance however as good as the measures the police take are, they will not on their own solve the kne crime problem. Part of the issue we have got to address is the step before someone carries a kne. Preventative work and early intervention is as important as everything the police do. Dr Mark Prince runs the The Kiyan Prince Foundation, which works with young people to end violence. His son Kiyan, , was stabbed to death on May , , receiving a single lethal kne wound as he intervened to stop the bullying of another teen.   Dr Prince said: Work like this does make a dference because every area has to be responsible for the part that they play and for enforcing the law. You could have been on the way to using that kne and because you’ve been caught you’ve saved a le, so there is sense behind the enforcement and we need that. It’s collective - everybody needs to be doing their part. MP Stephen Timms, who was stabbed at one of his constituency surgeries in May , added: I’m pleased the Met is putting so much emphasis on confiscating knives. story: NewsIncredible photos show mum giving birth in outdoor bathtub without medical helpWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES: Hannah Taylor gave birth to her son Koa in an "incredible, blissful, experience" with just her husband Tyler and no-one telling her to pushShareCommentsByPatricia MurphyChris kitching:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video meet-woman-who-gave-birth-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThese are the incredible photos of a first-time mum giving birth in an outdoor bath tub after choosing to forego medical help during the delivery. Hannah Taylor grew up with “scary” stories about childbirth from her own mum and wanted a serene experience for her son Koa. The -year-old yoga teacher decided the best option for her and her son - now aged three months - was a freebirth without a medical attendant or professional present. Hannah and her partner Tyler Couchman welcomed lb oz baby Koa in an outdoor bath with no-one telling her to push, describing it as an incredible, blissful, experience. Just Tyler and best friend Shea Zamarra were in attendance. Hannah, from the US city of Sacramento, Calornia, said: “My mum had traumatic births with me and my sister and it didn’t sit well with me. “Growing up I had only heard scary stories of birth and when I heard about my friend’s experience with unassisted birth. It felt right to me.  “A unassisted birth is one without medical intervention. You give birth unhindered and without medical interference.“No one telling you when to push, you just completely listen to your own body. “During my pregnancy I did a lot of research and I read a lot of books. I listened to podcasts focused on women and their unassisted birthing stories.  She added: “I went into labour in early morning at about am on October  and my active contractions started around .am. “I was just home with my partner and my best friend Shea. I hadn’t planned to move to the outside to the tub, I just wanted to use it as somewhere to take a break during labour. “I was on the floor of my room when I decided to move outside to the tub. It is connected to the warm water mains from our house.  “It was an incredible, blissful, experience and I was ecstatic. Meeting my little boy for the first time was incredible.” Hannah and her sister, Jessica Taylor, were born by Caesarean section which left her keen to explore other options during her own pregnancy. Unassisted birth is the process of having a baby without the presence of a medical attendant or professional, which Hannah believed was the best option for her family. Hannahs partner Tyler, , a chef, added: So far it was the most amazing experience of my le. I had never heard of free birth before, but catching my son in my arms was the most amazing thing. Holding him brought tears to my eyes. It felt like a dream.  While Hannah’s birth was unassisted, the mum did attend regular prenatal appointments with a midwe to make sure her pregnancy was healthy. Hannah said she would have rethought her plans had there been a health issue or potential danger for Koa. She said: “I had a healthy pregnancy and I visited a midwe all along. I had prenatal care. “There was no sign that anything was wrong, andthere had been I would have had to think about changing my plan.  “Depending on the severity I would have had to consider a hospital birth in that case. But I really made sure I had done a lot of research. Hannah has described her first three months as a mom to be “blissful” and she will always feel blessed to have had such a serene birthing experience. Hannah said: “The sun was out and it was beautul. I felt extremely powerful. “A few days afterwards he was checked out and everything was great. “I think all people should follow their hearts. I did what I thought was the best thing for my baby. “An unhindered birth allowed the experience to be sacred and it was incredible. I have never felt so connected to my body. I felt very blessed. “He’s so wonderful. I underestimated my capacity for love.”

story: A Dundee butcher bagged two awards in this year’s World Championship Scotch Pie Awards.Grossett Butchers won gold in the football pie category for its Mexican chilli cheese pie sold at Dundee FC, as well as landing bronze in the Scotch Pie category.The awards, organised by Scottish Bakers, saw more than  butchers and bakers enter more than  pies, sausage rolls, bridies, savouries and apple pies, making it a busy day for the judges.A spokesman for Grossett Butchers said: “We are delighted with our win and can go away with our heads held very high indeed.“To have been judged as one of the best in the land against so many of our peers is a huge achievement.”Head judge Ian Nelson said: “The competition, which has run for  years, aims to highlight that bakers and butchers create high quality pastry products.“Recognising the ‘great and the good’ in this way rewards excellence and raises the bar in the industry.”The awards were presented by TV personality and entrepreneur Carol Smillie, who said: “Each and every butcher and baker here today knows they make something special so a confirmation of this kind is the real icing on the cake.”

story: Young Kayden Smith has been rewarded for his generosity with a special tour of his local Asda.The Tele reported last year that the nine-year-old uses his £ pocket money to buy items for Dundee Foodbank rather than himself when out with his grandma.Staff at the Kirkton store said they were so moved by his actions they invited the St Fergus RC Primary pupil for a special tour of the supermarket.Asda Kirkton community champion Sam Will said: “Kayden didn’t quite realise how touching his kindness is, as I think it’s second nature to him, but it really does make everyone who knows about it feel happy and a bit more optimistic.”Kayden’s mum Denise said: “Kayden is the most caring, selfless little boy and he will do anything for anybody. I feel like crying when I think about what he does.“He saw the foodbank donation trolley in the store and said it made him sad there are people in this world who don’t get food so he wanted to use his pocket money to help get food for people and make them feel happy.”

title: dundees bob servant creator neil forsyth links up with game of thrones star for bbc drama
story: A drama written by the creator of Broughty Ferry’s own Bob Servant and directed by a Dundee filmmaker will be one of the flagship shows of BBC Scotland’s new digital channel.Guilt, penned by Neil Forsyth, is among a host of new programmes commissioned for Scottish viewers.The Broughty Ferry man links up again with Scottish actors Mark Bonnarand Jamie Sivesfor the drama which follows two brothers involved in a hit-and-run.Neil, , worked with Bonnar on Eric, Ernie and Me, a television film based on comedy legends Morecambe  Wise and their writer Eddie Braben.And Neil is not the only local involved in the project, with fellow Dundonian Robbie McKillop in the director’s chair.Speaking to the Tele from Los Angeles, Neil said: “I had wanted to write something about two brothers for a while, and the idea of throwing them into a dramatic, scary situation.“The first thing I thought of was the opening scene, of them hitting someone in their car and trying to cover it up and I really just wrote it out from there.”He added: “I obviously know Mark from Eric, Ernie and Me and quickly in the writing of the show I thought he’d be perfect for the older brother.“I’d also thought about Jamie Sives for the younger brother and then, coincidentally, when I spoke to Mark after the first time he read the script, he suggested Jamie too.“Everyone involved in making the show is delighted with getting the two of them. We did a little, first rehearsal last week just with Mark and Jamie and they’re just perfect. It’s really exciting.“Robbie McKillop went to school with my wee sister Carol, I played football with him in London for the South London Tangerines and my mum told me this week my granny and his were best pals in Broughty Ferry. So I knew him socially and was aware he was building a really good career.“Myself and the producers met with Robbie to discuss the show and were very impressed by his ambition and energy. I can’t wait to see what he does with it.”Neil believes the new channel can provide a greater  for Dundonians.He said: “It sounds great, BBC Scotland has been really supportive with Guilt which has been in development for over a year now.“Hopefully lots of Dundonian creatives are working on shows to pitch to the channel.”

title: jim mcintyre relieved as dundee remain in scottish cup
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre was relieved to still be in the Scottish Cup after his side scraped a draw with Queen of the South at Dens Park.Saturday’s fourth-round clash saw the Doonhamers deservedly move ahead through veteran striker Stephen Dobbie’s rd goal of the campaign.Although Jesse Curran struck a fine equaliser at the end of the first half, it was to prove the Dark Blues only shot on target over the  minutes.It was down to the heroics of debut keeper Seny Dieng, on loan from QPR for the rest of the season, that McIntyre’s men can look forward to a replay at Palmerston next week.And Jim conceded they were outplayed for much of the  minutes by the visitors.However, on a day of shock results that saw Motherwell and Ayr United go down to lower level opposition, Aberdeen held at home by Stenhousemuir and St Mirren having to battle back from two goals down against Alloa to edge through, being in the hat for the fth-round draw was a consolation.It will see Dundee face the Dons or Stenny away –they can come through the second game.“I thought Queen of the South were better than us. We didn’t start the game well,” said Jim.“These cup games are always dficult. Just look at the results around the other clubs and there’s been a few shocks.“I’m just glad that we’re still in the cup and we have another chance to recty that performance. We all know it was short of what we’re looking for.”If he was unhappy with his team’s work, the manager did stress the quality Queens showed did not surprise him.“You’ve got to credit Queen of the South. Give them a bit of credit, they played well.“You know what it’s like when a Championship or lower team comes to a Premiership club. You know they are going to be right up for the game and you know you are going to be in a fight.“They beat Ross County - last week which was a fabulous result against a team who’ve just knocked Motherwell out.”On top of getting another chance, Jim was pleased with the debuts he handed to Dieng, Craig Curran and second-half subs Andy Dales and Andrew Nelson.“The positives for me were the introduction of the newer players who all contributed and there will be better days ahead for us.”

title: jim mclean saddened by the waygoing of tannadice legends
story: It’s always sad when a football legend moves on from a club.However, that is the nature of the game, and spaces have to be freed up for new talent brought in or coming through.I can remember a couple of Dundee United-supporting friends being upset when Andy Rolland left the club.They felt, at that time, he could still do a good job for the team.Signed from Cowdenbeath in , Rolland, nicknamed “The Galloping Major”, would stay for  years at Tannadice.United wanted him to stay on but the player had an offer from American club Fort Lauderdale Strikers.Given his tremendous service in playing well over  games for the Terrors, the club immediately granted him a free transfer in September .He said at the time: “This offer has come right out of the blue.“Fort Lauderdale phoned me on Thursday, wanted me to travel on Saturday, and then play my first game for them on Sunday.“But that was too rushed for me.“I expect to go sometime next week.”He continued: “It’s a great offer, and I had to accept.“However, it’s a wrench leaving United after all these years.“Fort Lauderdale have offered me a -month all-year contract, but I’d rather come home when the main season finishes.”Tannadice manager Jim McLean was sorry to see his full-back go.“We will miss him – off the field as well as on it,” he said.“Since I’ve come into Tannadice, we have now lost three great long-serving players – Dennis Gillespie and Doug Smith being the others.“All of them were outstanding club men, and great examples for our young players.”The Dundee United directors also showed their appreciation of his loyalty by making a special payment to him in lieu of a benefit.On ing from America, where he also turned out for Los Angeles Aztecs, Rolland spent two years with Harry Melrose’s Dunfermline, before ending his playing career back at Cowdenbeath.He also managed the Central Park side for a spell.

title: no excuses from nathan ralph for dundees poor cup display
story: If excuses were his thing, full-back Nathan Ralph wouldn’t be short of a few to explain Dundee’s below-par display as they were held at home by second-tier Queen of the South in the Scottish Cup on Saturday.After the three-week winter break, the Dark Blues were not alone in looking rusty as they faced up to the Doonhamers at Dens Park.Elsewhere, as other Premiership outfits got back to competitive action for the first time since the turn of the year, the fourth round saw Motherwell crash out at home to Ross County and Aberdeen held by minnows Stenhousemuir.Dundee were also facing a team that has been in fine form of late and who, in veteran Stephen Dobbie, can boast one of the best strikers in the country, not just the Championship.That they came to Dens and turned in a high level of performance should have come as no surprise.Last, and certainly not least, what turned out to be the first leg of this tricky tie saw Dundee hand debuts to no fewer than four players in the shape of goalkeeper Seny Dieng and attackers Craig Curran, Andy Dales and Andrew Nelson.With so many new faces involved, it was perhaps understandable the home team’s play at times lacked cohesion, though ironically at the weekend it was generally speaking the new players who were the pick of the bunch.That’s all the get-outs listed and Ralph isn’t too interested in any of them. For him, the bottom line is Dundee should have been better than this.“It was very frustrating on Saturday. I think our performance first half, we should be thankful we are still in the cup really,” he said.“It wasn’t good enough. They’ve got the goal to go ahead and then Jesse has done brilliantly just before half-time to get it back and have us level.“It was a good time for us to score and then we did definitely play better in the second half. On the whole, though, it was not good enough.“I suppose it does happen in the cup, we saw that with some of the other results, and the big thing is we are still in there and have a replay where we can make it into the next round.“So we maybe shouldn’t be too hard on ourselves over it but we’re still not happy with the performance.”Like most players after a bad game, now the -year-old just wants to get out on a pitch again and try to put things right.That’s why he breathed a sigh of relief on Sunday when Hearts’ televised clash with Livingston produced a result.Had the Jambos not edged past the Lions, a replay would have been tonight and Dundee’s Premiership visit to Tynecastle would have been postponed.“We have another game right away and that’s good. The one thing we didn’t want was no game this week because Hearts had drawn their cup-tie.“The thing you want to do after the winter break is get back into playing regularly again right away and you don’t want to be missing games because of things like that. You want to get points on the board as soon as possible.”Turning to the subject of the new arrivals, Ralph believes they will signicantly boost the chances of top-flight survival.So far, he’s been impressed by what he’s seen.He added: “I thought the new lads looked sharp and direct. They definitely want to get on the ball, create and make things happen.“I think them coming in this month will be good for the squad and they are going to help us going forward.”

title: one in and one out for dundee united as goalkeeper signs from hibs
story: Dundee United have signed goalkeeper Ross Laidlaw on loan from Hibs as Matej Rakovan departs the club.The Tangerines have sealed a loan deal until the end of the season for the -year-old after releasing Slovakian goalie Rakovan with  months remaining on his contract.Laidlaw has played  times for the Hibees, winning the Championship in  in the process, and will challenge with Benjamin Siegrist for the gloves at Tannadice.Manager Robbie Neilson said: “Ross joins us to compete for the first-team goalkeeping position.#He brings important experience having won this championship with Hibs and most importantly is an excellent goalkeeper.#I have been looking to improve the competition within the goalkeeping set-up, and I am happy to see Ross here.“Rakovan played  times for the Tangerines, keeping one clean sheet.

title: plans to serve dundee angus and perthshire pupils frozen school dinners instead of fresh meals
story: Tayside schoolchildren could soon be eating frozen school dinners instead of fresh meals prepared in city schools.The council is proposing to change its school meal provision from cooking on site to cooking them at a central hub and distributing them to schools.Dundee, Angus and Perth and Kinross councils are considering the proposals, with the cuisine centre in Dundee set to undergo a multi-million-pound transformationplans are approved.Dundee City Council would contribute £, towards the refurbished centre, while Tayside Contracts would be approved to borrow up to £. million from the council’s prudential loans fund to fund the work.If agreed, the move would result in the loss of  posts across the city’s schools, although it is anticipated the centralised facility would create a total of  jobs.Tayside Contracts, which handles the distribution of school meals in the region, said it would not enforce compulsory redundancies.Stuart Fairweather of Unite the Union, which represents some affected workers, said: “There will be concern among staff that any redundancies relating to the changes are not voluntary.“More broadly there will be thoughts on the implications of the changes to the service.“We want well-supported staff with the resources to provide quality meals. Any staff with concerns should contact their trade union representatives.”A report by Dundee council officials said: “We plan to change and modernise the way primary schools, early learning and childcareand community meals are delivered across Tayside.“The proposal is to provide school and community meals through a Tayside Meal Centre.“This will signicantly improve the cost-effectiveness of the community meals service.”The report acknowledges there is a risk of “signicant reduction in school meal uptake” due to a “misperception” frozen food is inferior to fresh food.The report argues that nutritional quality and standards will be easier to maintain and calls the current method of meal preparation in schools “outdated”.Tayside Contracts currently provides about . million school meals to  primary schools throughout Tayside. The meals are made in  production kitchens and transported to  schools.Children and families committee convener Stewart Hunter said: “If it is delivered effectively then the evidence from other areas where this system is used is that just as many pupils and service users take the meals as before the change.”

title: scottish government secretary visits dundee for new benefits system roll out
story: Parents at Quarry View Nursery were visited by the Cabinet Secretary for Social Security yesterday as a new benefits system gets set to be rolled out.Shirley-Ann Somerville was in Dundee to discuss the new School Age Payment which, as part of the Best Start Grant, will see families receive £ to help cover the costs of starting school. While visiting parents, Ms Somerville confirmed it will be available from June  once regulations are approved.She said: “There’s no similar type of payment with the DWP currently, so this is a new payment that the Scottish Government is bringing in to ensure we are supporting families on low incomes.“It demonstrates that within Scotland we are building a new type of system that supports people to claim for benefits that they are entitled to.“We all know whether it’s beginning nursery or school, it can be an expensive time for families and it’s very important with these package of measures as part of the Best Start Grant that people claim what they are entitled to so they can enjoy going into P.”One of the parents benefiting from the new system is Terry Swan, , a family support worker from Fintry, whose daughter Derry, , will be starting school soon.She said: “Although you get the school clothing grant, it’s sometimes not enough. I wasn’t going to be able to get my daughter a blazer because they’re so expensive. With the extra money, it’ll be worthwhile seeing her standing smart in her blazer.“The extra money will mean she can get it so she can be like all her friends. Because of Universal Credit, sometimes it’s dficult to tell what you’re entitled to.”Parents and carers will be eligiblethey are responsible for a child and receive certain qualying benefits such as Universal Credit, income support and child tax credit. Ms Somerville confirmed a separate payment for children coming into early years education will be introduced later this year.

title: tesco delivery driver gets back at 3 30am to find thief in his dundee home
story: A Dundee man chased a housebreaker down a quiet West End lane after catching him rling through his belongings in his bedroom.Graham Menzies, , ed to his flat in Westfield Place in the early hours of yesterday morning to find the raider sorting his belongings into two piles on his bed.The housebreaker, who police believe had been scared away during an attempt to break into another house just  minutes earlier, fled the scene in the direction of Perth Road, pursued by Mr Menzies.Tesco delivery driver Mr Menzies said: “I came home just about .am and he was already in the house raking through my things.“He was sorting things into two piles of things he wanted to steal or leave behind.“I have a Superdry hoodie which he had put all the valuables on like he was going to carry them in that.“He came running out and I followed him down the street and then phoned the police.”Mr Menzies said his flat, which he shares with a flatmate, and the upstairs property had both been empty when the raider broke in.Police investigating the break-in say they believe the hapless raider had also been disturbed as he tried to break into a property on Perth Road around .am.The would-be thief again fled the scene after being disturbed as he tried to gain access to the property through a window.Officers said the suspect is a white male who was described as being of slim build.He was unshaven and was wearing a baseball cap and a dark jacket, carrying a rucksack and another white bag.A spokesman for Police Scotland’s Tayside Division urged homeowners to ensure properties are secured.He said: “We would like to remind everyone in the area to make sure your doors and windows are closed and locked, particularly at night.”Anyone with information that could assist police with their inquiries should contact Police Scotland on .Alternatively, they can contact Crimestoppers anonymously on   or speak to any officer.

title: thousands of dundee kids taking part in arts projects that are transforming their lives
story: Thousands of Dundee primary school pupils are now taking part in arts projects that are said to be “transforming” their lives.Reports to go before Dundee City Council’s children and families services committee on Monday show how Aspire Dundee and Big Noise Douglas are inspiring children and communities through the innovative application of dance, drama and music.Stewart Hunter, children and families service convener, said: “These two projects show the ambition we have for our pupils.“Aspire Dundee has been running for more than five years and now nearly , pupils are involved across  primary schools and four early years establishments.“I am impressed by the enthusiasm and the energy that surrounds this initiative and the positive impact it is having on children and their attainment, as well as their families and communities.“Big Noise Douglas is proving how a strong partnership with Sistema Scotland and Optimistic Sound can achieved so much in the Douglas community. The popularity of after-school clubs and a performance with Nicola Benedetti at the Caird Hall show how Big Noise is really making an impact.“Our schools are pioneering approaches that will benefit these children as they move through the education system and beyond.”

title: tom duthie time has come for dundee united to finally show their true title credentials
story: From the low of a shock end-of-year defeat at Alloa leading to fears the goal for the rest of the regular season would be to secure a play-off spot, things are suddenly looking up for Dundee United.The arrival in person of new owner Mark Ogren came with a pledge to give manager Robbie Neilson the funds he needs to get promotion.And perhaps, just as importantly, the promise this is a long-term project andit doesn’t happen this term, money will be ploughed in to make sure it does next. It gave everyone with a liking for the Tangerines a lt.So, too, did a dramatic shrinking of the seven-point gap at the top of the Championship courtesy of Neilson’s team taking four points from consecutive home games, while top two Ross County and Ayr United each lost two in a row.That means, for a few hours at least, United can join leaders County on the -point markthey win the second tier’s game of the weekend at Ayr on Friday night.They would, of course, still trail the Staggies, who have a vastly superior goal dference, but just being up there would be another boost.A win would also cancel out the game in hand Ayr hold over United, though they too have a better goal dference. And whatever happens at Somerset Park, Ian McCall’s team will be above themthey beat Inverness next midweek.Perhaps, though, the biggest benefit to United this weekend can be the type of performance that, whatever the points, makes a statement that they’re the ones to beat. That, unfortunately, is something they’ve largely failed to do in three seasons down in the Championship.Past glories, some of them recent, mean United start every campaign as favourites for promotion.And any team walking into Tannadice on a Saturday sees a club geared for football in the Premiership.Too often, however, any edge that’s given United has disappeared because of performances.Even when they’ve lost, in the last two-and-a-half years sides have come out of games against them feeling reputation and expectation have not matched the sum of the parts of the team they’ve faced.Results like two defeats away to Dumbarton the season before last, a - loss at Falkirk last term and two five-goal home losses in this campaign, have led to opposition throughout the ision believing they always have a chance when facing United.In truth, even the draw with Partick Thistle this month and the win over Dunfermline that closed the gap at the top to those three points, were not as convincing as was expected.That’s repeatedly been the case during the two failed attempts to get up. In the big games, too often United have come up short.They did beat Hibs at Tannadice near the end of  but lost heavily to them soon after and quickly dropped off the pace at the top.Andthey won twice at Tannadice against last season’s table toppers St Mirren, the first time came before the Buddies were regarded as their main rivals and the second after Jack Ross’s team were out of sight at the top.This time round, the best so far came up in Dingwall in November when County were beaten -.Without taking anything away from that success, after Paul Watson’s early goal put them ahead, the three points were secured via a gritty rearguard action.Yes, it was the kind of performance that is needed at times in a successful league campaign.So, too, do emphatic victories that tell the rest of the league you are a team to be feared. There would be no better time for such a statement than Friday in Ayrshire.

title: unemployment on rise in dundee
story: The unemployment rate in Dundee has risen slightly year-on-year, according to the latest UK Government statistics.The Department for Work and Pensionshas published new figures covering those who claim out-of-work benefits that it says better represents the city’s workforce.Under the new “alternative claimant count” produced by the DWP, .% of the city’s eligible workforce – or , people – aged - are not currently employed.The figure, for November last year, is a slight rise on  when .% of the city’s workforce was out of work.However, youth unemployment – covering - year-olds – has fallen by % in the last year and by more than a third since .Ministers claim the new figure is a more accurate measure of local labour markets.Under the old system, the proportion of those claiming out-of-work benefits was .% in November , rather than what the government now says is the more accurate figure of .%.The claimant count covers people claiming Jobseeker’s Allowanceand those required to look for work while on the new-style Universal Credit benefit, rolled out in Dundee in November .Jane McEwen, employment and partnership manager at the Dundee City Jobcentre, said she and her team were continuing to introduce initiatives to help those who can work find jobs.She said: “We are working with Sinclair Wellbeing to deliver an employability provision for customers that includes increasing motivation and confidence.“This employability course will also focus on health and wellbeing and how to become a ‘better version of yourself’.“It also looks at body language and other aspects that employers notice.”Dundee’s Jobcentre is also planning a number of events to support Hospitality Works, a national campaign to encourage an uptake in jobs in the service sector.The campaign launches on February .Across Scotland, unemployment has dropped below , for the first time.UK Employment Minister Alok Sharma said the government’s “pro-business policies” have boosted job prospects.He added: “There are , more people in work over the past year, almost entirely driven by full-time jobs as the government delivers an economy that works for the British people.”

title: virgin media closes dundee city centre store with immediate effect
story: Phone and broadband firm Virgin Media has announced it is closing one of its two city centre stores with immediate effect.A notice outside the media giant’s branch in the Overgate shopping centre announced the store would be closed from today, meaning the loss of several jobs.The company said the closure is part of a review to ensure its stores are in the right location for future growth plans.One member of staff, who declined to be named, said jobs were being lost as a result of the closure. He said: “We’re closing on Wednesday but staff haven’t been redeployed where.”A Virgin Media spokesman said staff had been notied of the closure.He added: “We often review our retail estate to ensure we have stores and kiosks in the right locations to support our growth plans.“Following a recent review, our Dundee store is closing.“We have been working closely with the employees impacted since November to guide them through a comprehensive consultation process and to identy other potential opportunities.”Alison Henderson, CEO of Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce, said: “Larger national retailers are continually evaluating their physical presence and how that fits with an increasing online sales environment.“Dundee’s city centre has definitely improved in recent years as we’ve seen independent businesses come in and help fill the gaps that have come from national brands as they rationalise.”The Overgate declined to comment on the latest closure.
