title: Bid to create new whisky centre by Loch Ness
story: TALES of illicit whisky distilling on the shores of Loch Ness may feature soon in a new visitor centreplans for the facility get the go ahead from Highland Council.Hospitality and tourist operator Cobbs is teaming up with the Dingwall-based GlenWyvis Distillery to create what is being billed as the Loch Ness Whisky Experience.If approved by planners it will be sited in a redeveloped cottage by the lochside Clansman Hotel, which Cobbs owns.GlenWyvis Distillery opened in late  as the worldrsquos first  per cent community-owned, fully sustainable distillery producing single malt whisky and craft gin.It was denied permission to open its own on-site visitor centre last year amid concerns about accessibility, though it says it is still working with the council to resolve that situation.Highland Councils transport planning team are seeking more information on a number of matters related to the proposed Loch Ness development, including traffic impact and access to the A public road, but Cobbs managing director, Fraser Campbell, believes it is an exciting project with huge potential."Abriachan and the area around the Clansman Hotel was well known for illicit stills and I know the distillery has a lot of information and history which will feature at the visitor centre," he said."It is important we bring more tourists to the area and give them things to do when they are at Loch Ness."The Clansman runs fantastic boat trips, but not everyone wants to go on a boat so we want to bring other visitor experiences to the loch."We approached the distillery. They think itrsquos a great idea and we think its a great idea and of course it will be a great means of promoting their product."He added: "We get lots of bus tours from Invergordon to the hotel and this development will also help reduce traffic and help the environment because it means they will not have to spend half a day on the road travelling to a whisky experience where."GlenWyvis managing director John Mckenzie said: "This opportunity has come at the perfect time for GlenWyvis. It will give us access to a global audience and it will provide a great forum to engage with visitors who are interested in the story of whisky from a Highland community perspective. This is about the story of grass-roots distilling, distilling for the people, and, of course, that is what underpins the community ethos of GlenWyvis."The aim is to have the new visitor attraction up and running by this summer but to develop it further after that, providing both interactive and interpretative displays, as well as a retail facility.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Broken lift leaves Inverness retirement flats residents stranded
story: RESIDENTS of a retirement complex in Inverness have been left disappointed, disgusted and even frightened by a range of issues which they say goes well beyond simple teething troubles.Problems affecting the Oakwood Court development in Crown ndash which is built on the grounds of the former Inverness Royal Academy building ndash include a lt which has repeatedly broken down, leaving some elderly residents effectively stranded on the upper floors, leaking pipes and badly sealed showers which have resulted in waste water and raw sewage seeping into some flats.The car park is also poorly lit and therefore a trip hazard.Residents of the -flat site are now contemplating legal action against operator McCarthy and Stone.Residents also have concerns about the electric supply and telephone system, with telephone lines not connected or fitted in wrong flats.Resident Paul Wells said problems with the lt were the biggest issue.ldquoWe have  apartments and only one lt, which is totally unreliable, he said.The lt broke down on seven occasions between late August and the end of the year, including four days over Christmas.ldquoSome people just didnrsquot go out of their apartments because of it, it was pretty dismal, Mr Wells said.Mr Wells said there were also safety issues in the car park.ldquoWe have some very uneven surfaces and so far we have had four residents trip over at night because lighting in one part is virtually non-existent, he said.ldquoAs you can imagine, wersquore pretty fed up. We donrsquot see it as being trouble-free living at the moment. We have paid over the odds for our apartments because we were after a certain lestyle and Irsquom sure we will get it, but in the meantime, it is very frustrating and frightening for some of our residents and, in terms of the car park, quite dangerous.The residents raised their concerns in a meeting with McCarthy and Stone management , but remained unsatisfied with the response. They are now speaking to a lawyer about the possibility of legal action, Mr Wells revealed.A spokeswoman for the firm said it was very sorry to hear about the problems, but it had been working hard to resolve defects.ldquoIn line with our commitments to all of our customers, we will ensure that any such faults are rectied as quickly as possible with the minimum of inconvenience, she added, and encouraged customers to raise any concerns with staff.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Bucket loads of fun in store for Inverness
story: A CHILDRENrsquoS hospital charity is teaming up with one of Scotlandrsquos most iconic characters ndash and is on the hunt for someone to co-ordinate the Inverness end of the operation.This summer will see the Oor Wullie Big Bucket Trail rolled out across the country with more than  inidually decorated statues of the cheeky comic character set to grace city streets between June  and September .As well as drawing attention to the work of The Archie Foundation an auctioning off of the figures at the end of the event is also expected to raise thousands of pounds for its work in making hospital stays more pleasant for children.Around  of the statues are set to grace Inverness streets and an invitation has already been issued for creative types young or old to submit their ideas for how they should be designed.There is also a vacancy for a part-time artist co-ordinator to ensure the work is delivered by the June deadline.A spokesman for the foundation said the role would suit someone with an arts background who can co-ordinate submissions and manage artists.ldquoWe have just taken delivery of the fibre glass sculptures at a warehouse in Dundee and they will be distributed around the country in due course, he said.In terms of the designs to be applied to the statues he added: ldquoWhen we say we are looking for lsquoartistsrsquo to decorate these sculptures we are very flexible, because in Dundee we have already had one decorated by a group of children putting their handprints all over the sculpture. Sothere are community groups out there who would like to give their take on Oor Wullie we would be delighted to hear from them too.Design ideas can be submitted online until January  at www.oorwullie and applications for the co-ordinator post should be emailed to hello@archie.orgThursday  Jan  : AM

title: Chance to win a kilt and help Inverness charity
story: KILT wearers are being offered the chance to win themselves a custom-made kilt package worth pound to help an Inverness appeal.A made-to-measure kilt, tweed jacket and waistcoat are being raffled to raise money for the Haven Appeal to develop Scotlandrsquos first integrated centre for children and young people with multiple and complex needs.The raffle is being organised by Angus Beaton and Gary Smyth who teamed up to put the prize together.Both have family members with autism and also served together in the Queenrsquos Own Highlanders.Mr Beaton is a counter sales assistant at MacGregor Industrial Supplies in Henderson Road while Mr Smyth runs the family business, Scotkilt, in Harbour Road.ldquoI became aware of the Haven Appeal because my -year-old grandson, Kyle, was diagnosed with autism when he was very young, Mr Beaton said. ldquoHe would benefit from something like the Haven Centre.The pound million facility will have specialist indoor and outdoor play areas, respite flats, a community-run coffee shop and garden and offices.Mr Beaton and his colleagues at MacGregor Industrial Supplies raised pound for the appeal last year through raffles, bake sales and a tuck shop.Mr Smyth became involved in the appeal as he has a son with autism.ldquoAs like any family with this going on, it has its challenges and there needs to be more help in the Highlands for us all, he said.The jacket and waistcoat along with the kilt will be made for the winner at Scotkilt.The appeal, launched by the Elsie Normington Foundation and supported by the Inverness Courier, has raised pound. million towards the proposed Haven Centre to be built in Murray Road, Smithton.Tickets for the raffle, which will be drawn on March , cost pound each or people can donate via www.justgiving fundraising angus-beaton.Details of the project can be found on www.havenappeal.org.uk.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Demands to tear down Inverness eyesore that has lain empty for 20 years
story: FRUSTRATION is growing among community leaders over a lack of progress to tackle a long-standing eyesore within sight of Inverness Castle.B-listed Viewhill House has stood empty for more than  years and was in poor repair when it was ravaged by fire in .Since then, the roofless shell has remained a carbuncle on the city skyline, shrouded in scaffolding, overgrown bushes and weeds.Pat Hayden, chairwoman of Crown and City Centre Community Council, believes it is time to consider knocking it downthere are no feasible restoration plans for the building ndash once the home of Victorian engineer Joseph Mitchell and later a youth hostel.And a leading city chartered surveyor agreed, saying it was beyond economic repair.Mrs Hayden said the eyesore would ruin the view from the castle once it is turned into a visitor attraction, adding: ldquoThey are going to stand on the hill and look around them, see Viewhill and wonder what on earth it is.ldquoPersonally, I think it should be demolished. You cannot preserve something which is no longer viable. We have waited far too long for something to happen.She is due to meet Highland Council officials later this month to discuss the future of the site.Chartered surveyor Richard Smith, managing director of Allied Souter and Jaffrey, said Viewhill should come down.ldquoIt is worth absolutely nothing unless you get permission to demolish it because the renovation far outweighs its value, said Mr Smith, whose company handled the sale on behalf of the Youth Hostel Association.He also queried its listing which he claimed followed a hurried request from a council official and without a visit from the listings authority.ldquoIt was a bad listing from the point of view that it was not checked out properly, said Mr Smith, who gave a ldquostab-in-the-dark valuation of pound, for the site, based on permission for demolition and redevelopment for a residential property.At one time Viewhill was owned by building firm Ewen Gillies and later acquired by Magnus Propertieswhich is believed to be the present owner. The companyrsquos director has a correspondence address in County Antrim.Highland Council is not in active discussions with the owner and David Haas, Inverness city centre manager, said it was up to the owner to push forward any plans.ldquoAs a council, we recognise the importance of that site and will work with stakeholders who have responsibility for it to develop any opportunities, but at the moment we are not in a position to do that, he said.ldquoObviously, we are very keen to see it brought back into use.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister agreed action was now needed.ldquoI have spoken to other people who are really fed-up about it, she said. ldquoPeople think it is a disgrace.Highland Historic Buildings Trust previously pressed the case for the restoration and conversion of the property into eight-serviced apartments, but has been unable to raise the costs, estimated at pound. million in .Chairman John Duncan stressed the trust was not the owner or potential developer but got involved to try and find a solution.He said any application for demolition would have to be determined by the council and Historic Environment Scotland.In connection with another controversial Inverness building, aquestionmark hangs over when the former Eastgate Hostel will be demolished, despite previous assurances that eyesore would start to come down next week.Talks took placeon Thursdaybetween Highland Council and representatives acting for the owners of the building which has remained a fire-ravaged eyesore for  days now.Afterwards, neither party would confirm whether work would begin next week, although they insisted the meeting was ldquovery positive.Chiropodist Jim Crawford, whose business is nearby, called for the council to take out a compulsory purchase orderwork does not start by next Friday.ldquoThere has been no sign of activity so far, he said.ldquoIt is an absolute nonsense.Building consultant Gary Johnston, agent for the owners Imtaiz Ali and Mr Cheng, would not confirm when work would begin. All he could say was: ldquoEverything is going according to plan.David Haas, Highland Councilrsquos Inverness city manager, said matters were progressing in a constructive way.ldquoIt is very frustrating it has taken so many years to get to this stage but the principal owner has taken major steps in the last six months, he insisted.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Drive on to extend free parking in Inverness city centre
story: CITY businesses are pushing for an extension to free parking in the centre of Inverness as a year-long trial they have hailed as a success comes to an end.Backed by the Inverness Courier, Inverness Business Improvement Districtpersuaded Highland Council to introduce a system of free  minutes of on-street parking last year across a broad swathe of the city centre.Parking meters were converted to provide free tickets for  on-street spaces, after research suggested similar schemes have had a positive impact on footfall in other urban centres such as Perth.The trial period is now coming to an end and business figures, who argue it has been a hit, are hoping it will be extended ndash both in terms of the amount of time shoppers will be able to enjoy free parking for and the number of sites they can us.Local butcher Duncan Fraser who has premises in Queensgate said: ldquoThe businesses I have spoken to would like to see it extended to half an hour.ldquoFteen minutes is fine, but a bit tightyou have to go to a couple of shops or get caught up in the post office.ldquoWe certainly would not like to see this withdrawn.And David Miele, who runs the hugely successful Mielersquos Gelateria in Church Street, is also hoping councillors will look at making better use of the parking space available.ldquoThere are too many loading bays which lie empty for most of the day, he said.ldquoWhen wardens pass our premises customers basically get up and go out because they fear getting a ticket.ldquoI welcome the free parking and would like to see it increased.They are being backed in their calls by Inverness Central councillor and depute provost Bet McAllisterldquoIt has clearly been welcomed by the traders and enables people to get in to the town centre and attend to business, but you canrsquot do a lot in  minutes, she said.ldquoI would rather see it extended to half an hour so people can pop into a couple of shops, go to the library or even stop for a coffee.And she added: ldquoMany older people would benefit greatly from a longer stay.ldquoWe have to look at the bigger picture. The Victorian Market is generally used by older people and it needs more customers. Longer-stay free parking would help.BID manager Mike Smith said it believes the free parking has been beneficial.ldquoInverness BID subscribes to the view that parking is all part of the city centre marketing offer to the public, he said.ldquoWe appreciate the financial pressures Highland Council is under, but we should not lose sight of that mantra.Shane Manning, principal officer for traffic and planning at Highland Council, confirmed councillors are set to evaluate the schemersquos impact when the Inverness city area committee meets on February . They will decide at that point whether to continue with it.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Funding could lead to new life for Inverness park
story: A BOLD vision to transform a historic Inverness park into a vibrant green space and breathe new le into its dilapidated buildings could take a step forward later this month.Campaigners are exploring the possibility of transferring ownership of the Northern Meeting Park in Ardross Street to a community-run group in a bid to enable greater access to the venue.The Northern Meeting Park Group is now waiting to hear whether a funding application has been successful for a feasibility study to prepare a five-year business plan plus architectural reports and surveys.If all goes according to plan, the study could begin before the end of January while the long-awaited project could be achieved by the end of next year.The group is also looking for two trustees from the local community ndash taking in the neighbourhoods of Park, Balleary and Dalneigh and Columba ndash to join its -strong board.Chairman Jon Ford expects this year to be a busy one in trying to push forward the proposals for the -year-old park whose gates are usually kept locked.The group has applied for a grant from the Scottish Land Fund with advice from Highlands and Islands Enterprise and hopes to get match funding from the Architectural Heritage Fund.In total, the initial studies are expected to cost pound,.ldquoWe know there are a lot of other people out there also looking for funding but we are very optimistic, he said.ldquoThat would be the first stage. The next stage would be to apply for funding to acquire the Northern Meeting Park and have it transferred into community ownership.Highland Council would also have to agree to transfer ownership of the park.Mr Ford acknowledged there had been some resistance from a few councillors including those who had mistakenly thought the idea was to turn the park into a private business venture.ldquoNone of us likes change, he said. ldquoI can understand it on one level but not on another when you are talking about a publicly-owned asset which is kept locked up and not used especially as it is four acres of grass in the city centre which could be used for recreation.ldquoI cannot understand why people are resistant to that notion. In our view this is a way for Highland Council to think outside the box.Hundreds of people accessed the park during a two-week trial last summer when the gates were opened each day between am and pm.Mr Ford hopes a similar trial will be carried out around Easter.Anyone interested in becoming a trustee can contact the group via www.northernmeetingpark, or call  .Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Go ahead for River Ness hydro scheme
story: A SPECTACULAR hydro electric scheme close to the heart of Inverness has been given the green light by Highland Council, and it is hoped it will not only be a source of power, but also an attractive feature on the River Ness.Council officials granted the application for the lsquoArchimedes screwrsquo to be built into the bank next to Holm Mills Bridge near the West Link distributor road but have placed a total of  conditions on the project to safeguard visual amenity, road and pedestrian safety.The project has been warmly welcomed with local councillor Alex Graham, he said: ldquoThis project was first mooted about three years ago and then it came back towards the end of last year. Historically hydro power was generated there in the s in the building that is now the ice-cream shop.ldquoIn the present climate I think it is a very welcome project, one that can not only generate power locally but also become a feature to be enjoyed by visitors and locals.Helen Smith, who is on Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoWe didnrsquot comment on it but it is tucked away quite far from residential buildings. But from my point of view, personally its fine, I remember there was hydro power there in the past and it might be quite attractive. Irsquod be surpriseit bothers any local residents.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Highland arts venue has strategy to combat fund gap
story: THE regionrsquos biggest arts venue has outlined how it must become more financially resilient.In its latest accounts, Eden Court in Inverness reported increased income and more expenditure in the year ending March ,  compared to the previous  months.Last year Eden Court lost pound, a year of funding ndashpound, from Creative Scotland and pound, from the Highland Council.A trusteesrsquo report the figures stated: ldquoThe principal risks identied are financial ones, particularly the effect of this yearrsquos signicant reduction in public funding.ldquoThe organisation must become more financially resilient by growing sources of earned income and building a safe level of reserves.ldquoAs public funding declines, the targets for earnings from trading activities necessarily increase, and the risk that these targets cannot be met also increases. At the same time, our cost base is likely to increase owing to inflationary pressures on resources.ldquoThis year we are working on a strategy for trading through our funding gap, increasing income from charitable trading, reducing costs wherever possible and developing partnerships to share services.ldquoAttention has also been focused on non-financial risks arising from the loss of some channels of regular communication with our major funders our relationship with both Creative Scotland and the Highland Council has been strengthened during the year to March ,  and subsequently.ldquoThe development of positive relationships with funders ndash public organisations and inidual philanthropists ndash remains a high priority and is a central part of Eden Courtrsquos financial strategy for the coming three years.Total income increased from pound,, in  to pound,, last year. For the same period, total expenditure moved from pound,, to pound,,.Total funds also went up from pound,, to pound,,.Advance ticket sales mean that Eden Courtrsquos cash flow position remains strong.The biggest event of the year was the Snow White panto, which sold more than , tickets for its  performances.The report stated: ldquoAttendance for the year has been unprecedented with audiences of , for live performances and , at film screenings. The financial contribution from live performances was pound, higher than budget, boosted by some musical performances in the summer months and an excellent result from our Christmas pantomime.The wholly owned subsidiary Eden Court Trading experienced a rise in turnover from pound,, in  to pound,, last year, and an increase in pre-tax profit from pound, to pound,.The report added: ldquoOver the past four years we have seen substantial growth in trading through our restaurant, cafeacute and bars, and also in sales of confectionary, show merchandise and programmes by our front of house team.ldquoOur trading activities in   resulted in a surplus of pound,, an increase of  per cent over the previous yearrsquos result.ldquoWe will also implement a new strategy to attract philanthropy from trusts and foundations, and from within our community.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Hope that Inverness special needs project can be saved
story: Highland Councilrsquos refusal to fund the Special Needs Action Projectin Inverness has triggered outrage across party lines with councillors and members of parliament queuing up to slam the local authority.Conservative councillor Andrew Jarvie, said: ldquoNot only is this a devastating blow for dozens upon dozens of vulnerable children and young people, it symbolises everything that is wrong with this council administration.Mr Jarvie complained the decision to refuse funding was taken in private, saying: ldquoThis secrecy and behind closed door decisions wreaked havoc on rural communities last year but I find it absolutely disgusting to inflict the same on the most vulnerable people in Highland.ldquoFor SNAP to run such a comprehensive and valuable year round service for pound, a year tells me that they are already managing their funds stringently and that any cut is a gross insult to both the organisation and its users.MP Drew Hendry met with SNAP management last week and he said: ldquoAnybody who knows about the great work SNAP do would also be very concerned by the uncertainty around their future and just how dficult it would be to replace the work that they do.ldquoA better way forward must be to secure their immediate future and to work with them to find sustainable funding for coming years.ldquoThis approach has worked successfully before and I have pledged to do what I can to support SNAP and the council to find a better outcome.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Inverness schoolgirl coining it in thanks to generous donation
story: AN Inverness schoolgirlrsquos coin collecting hobby has received a boost after she was given a bag of assorted coins by a well-wisher.The man, who insisted on remaining anonymous, came to the Inverness Courier office with the money after we ran a story about Isla MacDonald becoming online coin club Change Checkerrsquos award-winning junior member of .Islarsquos interest in specially minted coins was sparked by the finding of a Girl Guides centenary p and now the Cradlehall Primary pupil has  special p coins and  dferently designed pound coins.Her father Simon helped her to research the first coin and she began keeping an eye out for other coins which are unusual and collectable.Her mother Luisa said: ldquoIt is a shame this man has asked to remain anonymous because we would love to write a thank you letter to him. It was really kind of him. Isla is delighted and fascinated by the selection of coins that was in the bag.Islarsquos coin collection includes several rare items, including coins marking the Commonwealth Games in England, London Underground and Paddington Bear.Like her fellow collectors, she is keeping a sharp eye out for Kew Gardens which remains the most scarce p coin currently in circulation.Among the gted coins is a  pound coin issued to mark  years since the Declaration of Rights being enacted which effectively shted the balance of power from the Crown to parliament and changed the course of British political history.Another is a pound coin which was minted in  to mark the centenary of Entente Cordiale, agreements made between the UK and French governments.Two Cornish halfpennies, and a pound and p from the Isle of Man are also included, as well as a square coin marking the bicentenary of the Battle of Jersey.Although not a coin, the bag included a highly nostalgic ldquoOfficial Licensed Medallion marking that Scotland had qualied for the  World Cup in France. Five World Cups have come and gone since without Scotland managing to qualy.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Loss of Inverness nightclub is sad for the city
story: THE closure of Club Tropicana brings to an end  yearsrsquo experience of working in Inverness nightclubs for Roy Dunnett.However, Mr Dunnett believes the closure is not just sad news for himself and the  colleagues who have been made redundant, but for Inverness as a whole.ldquoInverness used to have three big nightclubs, but now we have city status and a growing student population with the UHI and Inverness doesnrsquot have any, Mr Dunnett said. ldquoThere are plenty of drinking places in Inverness, but we lack a physical nightclub. A lot of stag and hen parties come up to Inverness now and they want to go to a club to finish their night, which they would do back home. They donrsquot want to be in a bar that serves food.Mr Dunnett also worked at Grsquos nightclub on Castle Street, which Club Tropicana owner TGC Leisure closed in May . However, he does not blame the owner for taking the decision to close the clubs but the council for licensing policy changes which allow pubs to remain open until am.ldquoThat put us at a disadvantage, he said.ldquoWe were charging people to get in whereas the bars were free entry. They can also make their money by serving meals during the day. We can only make our money from pm to am.Mr Dunnett also worries about the job prospects for some of his colleagues.ldquoWe employed a lot of single mothers who couldnrsquot work during the day because they couldnrsquot get childcare, he said.ldquoThey canrsquot get jobs in bars because the bars are open during the day.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: coming home its giving me a fresh start forrester re signs for league or ireland side st pats after aberdeen exit
story: Midfielder Chris Forrester has re-signed for League of Ireland side St. Pat#s after it was mutually agreed to terminate his Aberdeen contract.The £, summer signing from Peterborough departed Pittodrie yesterday and has now rejoined his former club on a three-year deal.Reds boss Derek McInnes cited Forrester#s desire toto Ireland when his departure was announced.On signing on at Richmond Park, Forrester said: #I#m absolutely delighted to be back with everything that#s gone on with my le.#I was always going to be coming back to Pat#s, it#s a club that#s very close to my heart.#Coming home, it#s giving me a fresh start. I#m around my family, I#m around my girl, my friends.#I#m back at a club that I think genuinely likes me.#

title: hamilton v aberdeen match report
story: Aberdeen continued where they left off in the Scottish Premiership with a convincing - win over Hamilton.It was the Dons# first league fixture since ing from the winter break and Sam Cosgrove#s double and a Lewis Ferguson effort gave them a deserved victory against struggling Accies at New Douglas Park.Reds boss Derek McInnes made one change to the side which was held to a - draw with Stenhousemuir in the Scottish Cup on Saturday. Stevie May was drafted in up front with Niall McGinn dropping to the bench.The first chance fell for the hosts on nine minutes. Dougie Imrie’s corner on the left was met by Matt Kilgallon  yards out, but the defender’s powerful header was brilliantly tipped onto the crossbar by keeper Joe Lewis.Aberdeen grew into the game after that with Greg Stewart’s dangerous free-kick from the left being uncertainly patted away by goalie Ryan Fulton.In the th minute a decent passing move from the Dons ended with Stewart finding Gary Mackay-Steven and the winger’s strike from  yards drted narrowly over.The outstanding moment of quality in the opening half hour resulted in Aberdeen taking the lead on  minutes.It started with Cosgrove winning a high ball on the right to feed, Mackay-Steven, he worked the ball infield for Stewart who moved possession to skipper Graeme Shinnie in the centre of the park.The Reds captain spread play to the left for Max Lowe who had bombed forward from left-back, the Derby loanee found May wide on the left, the striker’s right-footed cross found Cosgrove at the back post.The Englishman’s initial header across goal was blocked by Kilgallon but Cosgrove followed up and stabbed the ball home from eight yards.Shortly after the half hour Cosgrove was unlucky as he bundled Lowe’s cross from the left wide.Just before the break Aberdeen almost added a second on the break when Stewart set up Mackay-Steven but a heavy touch let him down.Aberdeen knew a second goal early in the second period would make it very dficult for the Accies to recover and they got it in the nd minute.Aaron McGowan tumbled in the Dons# box looking for a penalty, but ref Greg Aitken waved it away because Mackay-Steven had won the ball.Mackay-Steven then fizzed a long ball down the left flank for Cosgrove. The striker controlled and beat Ziggy Gordon with a mixture of strength, speed and skill.Then Cosgrove raced into the area and drilled home a low right-footed shot from  yards.On  minutes it was well and truly game over when Aberdeen made it -.Lowe won a corner on the left, May#s in-swinging delivery was headed by Cosgrove, Fulton saved but former Hamilton player Lewis Ferguson got the final touch almost on the goal-line to bundle the ball home.After that it was comfortable for the Dons, but they almost added a fourth when sub Scott Wright jinked his way down the left before curling a shot inches wide from just inside the box.With  minutes left there was a moment of panic at the back for Aberdeen as Mackay-Steven almost sold Lewis short with a back-pass, but the Dons goalie got to the ball before Scott McMann could profit.After that the Reds saw out the rest of the game with ease as Dons support of  in the crowd of  celebrated at New Douglas Park.Hamilton: Ryan Fulton, Aaron McGowan, Scott McMann, Ziggy Gordon, Matt Kilgallon, Dougie Imrie, Steve Davies , Mickel Miller , Tom Taiwo , Alex Gogic, Tony Andreu.Subs not used: Jacob Marsden, Alex Penny, Shaun Want, and Lenny Sowah.Aberdeen:  Joe Lewis, Shay Logan, Scott McKenna, Andy Considine, Max Lowe, Greg Stewart, Lewis Ferguson , Graeme Shinnie, Gary Mackay-Steven, Stevie May , Sam Cosgrove .Subs not used: Tomas Cerny, Niall McGinn, Dean Campbell and Tommie Hoban.

title: po britannia magic of life on the ocean wave
story: Sailing down a moonbeam at midnight is never guaranteed.But from the moment you step aboard the Britannia you sense this is going to be a magical experience, a transcendent journey that will take you into the heart of the Caribbean and beyond.This majestic ship – the jewel in the crown of PO’s cruise fleet – oozes sophistication with its plush five-star surroundings.The spectacular Star Burst sculpture, the centrepiece of her atrium, signals the magnitude of her beauty.And yet the ship underplays its excellence in a restrained and very British way.Under the steady command of Captain Wesley Dunlop, the , tonne vessel was to be home for my mum and I for  nights.Our sea passage was to take us a distance of , nautical miles, departing Bridgetown, Barbados, and on to Curacao, Aruba, Grenada, St. Vincent, St. Lucia, Dominica, Antigua and St Maarten.Within an hour of embarking the ship, warmed by the legendary Barbados rum punch, our cares blew away in the breeze as we chilled out for the sail away party on the lido deck, soaking up the heat beneath the Caribbean sun.It was very easy to get our Caribbean groove on thanks to the talented Lady B and her band, Steele, who had the sun-lounging crowd singing along to the classic hits of the late, great reggae maestro, Bob Marley.When it comes to choosing the right cruise line company to travel with, I’m looking for great value, great destinations and even greater food.And I can confidently say you would be hard pushed to find any to top this one.Britannia serves up the ultimate posh nosh.No matter where you choose to dine on board, whether it be the ultimate fine dining experience in the art deco-inspired Epicurean or the self-service Horizon buffet, the selection and quality of food and produce on offer is first class.From dining at Sindhi, where east meets west, with just the right twist of spice, to the lighter bites and hearty mains in the Glass House, the gastronomic experience is ied but always sublime.But you don’t have to take my word for it.Three-times Michelin star chef, Marco Pierre-White is patron of The Cookery Club, and when on board he hosts cookery masterclasses.The waters of the Caribbean Sea are warm and welcoming.Is it any wonder that Aruba, where it never rains, is known as the happy place  Grenada, with its lush green forests, is the island of spice,On rugged but picturesque St Vincent I found myself dipping my toes in a blue lagoon where the Pirates Of The Caribbean franchise is filmed, while – you guessed it – sampling again some very good rum punch. Hiccup, me hearties!Next stop was St Lucia, one of the Caribbean’s little treasures with its secluded beaches and colourful fishing villages.These are places to pick up a bargain from bustling markets, sample seafood delights, and stroll hand-in-hand along white sandy paradise beaches.Caribbean,  nights, £,ppPO Cruises is offering a  night cruise on Britanniafrom £, per person for an inside cabin. Departing November   the price includes flights from selected UK airports, kids’ clubs, full board meals and entertainment on board.Departing from and ing to Barbados ports of call are Curacao, Aruba, Grenada, St Vincent, St Lucia, St Kitts, Antigua, St Maarten.To book, visit www.pocruises, call    or visit your local travel agent.For more information click hereOn the ship there are numerous leisure options – designer boutiques, swimming pools, deck tennis, a state of the art gym and cookery club, live music, karaoke, big screen football in one of the many bars, cinema shows and the chance to have a flutter at the casino.The entertainment on board is pretty impressive, too.Gareth Gates headlined the bill in the Limelight Club and the ship’s theatre shows could easily give the West End a run for its money.There are also great clubs for the kids, so parents can have the odd guilt-free night-off.My mum, who has dficulty walking, made her own magical discovery on board. In the Spa Retreat she met acupuncturist Craig Bryson, who has close to  years experience in perfecting the ancient and traditional holistic treatment.Craig’s healing powers certainly helped to put a spring back in her step, which continued long after our Caribbean golden sunkissed tans had faded away.That the journey aboard the Britannia was in itself magic is no surprise. PO have been perfecting their craft for close to a century. They are true magicians of the high seas, conjuring a glorious travel experience from the finest destinations.To be gazing across the ocean as the Britannia follows the reflection of a moonbeam on its surface, drawn on by some celestial guiding light, is to feel immersed in the moment.Britannia, indeed you are cool.You are not a drop in the ocean.In fact, I would confidently go as far as to say, the ocean is a drop in you.

title: marian travels back to the hollow mountain
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsMy book about the project, Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain, was published to coincide with the th anniversary of its opening. Invited to join Cameron up at the Cruachan dam for the second of his two recent programmes, I was delighted to tramp the mighty mountain with Scotland’s Number one authority on outdoor pursuits.As an author and broadcaster, Cameron always has an eye on a good story, and so as well as asking me about the lack of health and safety regulations at the time the hydro project was being built, he also wanted to knowthere really was a murder during the construction. There was, as I told him, a body – but the body wasn’t identied, no arrests were made, no court case took place.It would be a shamethat construction period went down in history as an invasion of , workmen – #Tunnel Tigers# as they were dubbed – into one of Argyll#s most beautul settings and a possible murder.My book was intended to give the story of the local people whose lives were punctuated by this ambitious construction project. Quite rightly, those Tunnel Tigers had been lauded in a number of publications. The work that was done hollowing out Argyll’s highest mountain to provide electricity for the nation was amazing.The plan for Cruachan – as for the other major hydro projects of the post World War II era – was conceived by Tom Johnston, to whom I dedicated my book. Johnston was a politician who remained true to his ideals of bringing rural Scotland into the modern world. There was no power in the Highlands, and without power there could be no industry and no prosperity. The engineering genius was Sir Edward MacColl, whose biographer Norrie Fraser called him #a maker of modern Scotland#.Cruachan was the first reversible pumped-storage system in the world. During its years of construction from  to , eminent international engineers visited the project to see how the water was pumped between two reservoirs through reversible turbine generators. At off-peak hours, the water was – is # pumped back up to the reservoir you see high up in the corrie above Loch Awe, held back by a dam that is now so much a part of our landscape. The loch itself is the lower reservoir.I had imagined that the scale of such a project – using Scotland’s top engineering companies who shipped in workers from other parts of the UK and Europe – would have been a cause for resentment and protest by local people.That, of course, failed to take account of the vision of the folk of Dalmally, Lochawe, and Taynuilt. Although it took men with engineering experience to blast the  miles of tunnels, hollow out the mountain itself, and construct the dam, there was also a need for a support army. There were clerks and porters, joiners and caterers, folk willing to let out a room, a caravan, a house, serve in a pub where just occasionally it was necessary to keep a baseball bat behind the bar to maintain bonhomie. The project kick started careers, fortunes and marriages, and gave the area good roads and a tourist industry.If you haven’t visited the hollow mountain or walked Cruachan’s slopes, make  the year you do.[In bold please] Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain is available from the Argyll Book Centre in Lochgilphead and all good book shops, along with Marian Pallister#s other books of local interest.PICS:The Pass of Brander before work started. no_aCruachanLe before the project # the Loch Awe Hotel with steamers. no_aCruachanThe Queen opening the project in October . no_aCruachanWorking on the  miles of tunnels. no_aCruachanWorking on the road to the dam, overlooking Loch Awe. no_aCruachan

title: coleman and aliyev impress ardrishaig
story: Robert LaceyUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs the lights dimmed in Ardrishaig Hall on Saturday January , and the audience chatter subsided, two young men, dressed entirely in black, strode into view.Jâms Coleman sat at the splendid Yamaha grand piano that for all visiting musicians must be such a relief to see, while Jamal Aliyev carefully set the spike of his special Giovanni Gabrielli Cello , an instrument re-discovered after a -year absence from public performance.Then the music began and the dark first notes of Beethoven’s Cello and Piano Sonata op. no. in G minor filled the hall. It was written for Count Friedrich Wilhelm, supposedly simplied for amateurs to play. However, Jamal and Jâms being master musicians showed the power of this often disregarded piece, to be immense. One of the first works to make piano and cello equal musical partners, it is full of ingenious dialogue between the instruments. The structure is unusual, but with such expert performers it delighted the audience who were moved by every turn and twist of this deeply emotional work.Jâms, from North Wales, after remarking on the three ferry crossings required to get to Ardrishaig via Bute, introduced the next piece, Ernest Bloch’s work ‘From Jewish Le’. In a style close to Jamal’s heart and heritage, having been born in Baku Azerbaijan, its three elements, ‘Prayer’, ‘Supplication’ and ‘Jewish Song’, are full of the pathos and sorrow felt by the Jewish nation and also full of the signature augmented intervals and minor key tonality of much of middle eastern musics. How beautully these pieces demonstrated the lyrical qualities of the cello. Jamal’s bow searched for all possible nuances of tone and dynamic as his instrument sang from its lowest notes to a seductive soprano register.The concert continued after the interval with a second Beethoven work. The audience may have noticed a minor kerfuffle at the piano as many pages were rapidly turned before starting. Would it be the ‘Seven Variations’ for cello and piano or the ‘Twelve’, both based on themes from Mozart’s Magic Flute  The ‘Seven Variations’ won, being on the theme from the ‘Pamina’ and ‘Papageno’ duet entitled ‘In men, who know the feeling of love’. This work exhibits Beethoven’s practised ingenuity in the iation form and brought a lighter mood to the programme.Jâms Coleman introduced the final work, Frank Bridge’s Cello Sonata. He told of the four years of torment for the composer as he struggled to express his feelings about the First World War, finally finishing the composition in . The adagio in the piece caused the composer the most dficulty as he struggled with ambivalence about his own pacist views. Jâms and Jamal dealt with the challenges of this complex work which tracks huge changes in the world of music composition that were under way at that time. Again, the lyrical powers of the cello came to the fore as did the virtuosic requirements heaped on the pianist. Despite its undoubted innovations, this piece generously reaches out to its audience. Bridge uses the new musical freedoms only when justied, being happy toto more traditional tonal stability in the lyrical sections.Fulfilled, but not overburdened by the weightiness of the final piece, the audience applauded Jamal and Jâms back to the concert room to perform the ‘Swan’ from Saint-Saens ‘Carnival of the Animals’ as encore. This piece so beautully confirmed the excellence of Jamal’s playing and the superb quality of his quite special instrument.PIC:Jamal Aliyev and Jâms Coleman. no_aJamalandJam

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: new south ayrshire headteacher bagged
story: NewsNew South Ayrshire headteacher has bagged dream jobGaenor Hardy,, has assumed control at Heathfield in Ayr, complete with its  pupil roll and  child nursery.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN NewsGaenor Hardy "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe new boss of South Ayrshire’s biggest primary school has bagged her “dream job”. Gaenor Hardy,, has assumed control at Heathfield in Ayr, complete with its  pupil roll and  child nursery. And the shining star of the region’s education system confesses she is now “living in a bubble waiting for it to burst”. Gaenor, who joins Heathfield after heading up Dalmilling Primary for five years, said: “I was very happy there and only Heathfield would have pulled me away. “It is always the school I have aspired to. My twins came here and I feel that level of affinity. “All I see is potential. I’ve never been at a school where the surroundings in the community are so rich.” Gaenor cut her teaching teeth in south London before ing north after her sister suffered a severe stroke, aged just . She said: “It made me review my le and decide what was important so we relocated back up to Scotland. “I’ve been back here for  years now and always had one eye on Heathfield as I knew it was such an exciting job. “Part of that excitement is that I live in the catchment and my children went here so it feels like coming home. “But I’m also excited about making this the flagship school. “However, we also need to make this the hub of the local community.” Fitness fanatic Gaenor admits an “open and frank exchange of views” took place during the first meeting with her new parent council last week. It follows concerns over the previous management’s approach to alleged bullying within the school. But she insisted: “I’m all for honest, vibrant and lively dialogue. “None of it was a surprise to me as a parent myself. “I would hate to think I’ll be a comparison to previous management in the school. “What I can bring is my own unique experience to the role. “I want to be open and visible and have parents approach me. “This has to be us together on the journey.” And she added: “I don’t have to grow a passion for the school. It is there within me already. “I feel like I’m in a bubble of looking forward to coming to work and being so motivated – and I’m still waiting for it to be burst.” Now Gaenor, who is often seen walking to school, is planning to get her pupils into shape as part of a new physical and mental drive. She said: “If I want the children to be fit and healthy then I have to model that. “Health and wellbeing has to underpin everything we’re doing. “The local junor parkrun is an example of something I’d like to see encouraged. “We’ve also rolled out more than  after-school and lunch clubs from this month. “I’ll be doing a homework club and the clerical team are doing a running club so we’re all very hands on. “But ultimately the children are my inspiration. “We have a fantastic new building in which to work and I’ve never experienced anything like it during my career. “Now the challenge is to make the most of it and enjoy what we have.”

title: new super school riddled structural
story: NewsNew super-school is riddled with structural problemsLeaks, faulty automatic doors and sensory lights are among a string of issues at Invergarven’s marquee campus in Girvan.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsInside the school "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new pound million super-school is “riddled” with structural problems, it can been revealed. Leaks, faulty automatic doors and sensory lights are among a string of issues at Invergarven’s marquee campus in Girvan. The school’s swimming pool has also not been used since the ribbon was cut back in August. Council chiefs, who hailed the building as a huge boost for education, admit they have hit “snagging issues”. One senior source said: “The place was leaking like a sieve. “You expect the odd snag with any new building but this is far more than that. “It seems like the pressure was on to move in on time and clearly things haven’t been ready. “To be fair the place has been riddled with problems since day one.” The Post understands that a squad of up eight workers have been sent in to fix ongoing problems. And staff have still to be trained in using the hydrotherapy pool some five months after the school’s opening. Girvan councillor, Iain Fitzsimmons, said: “The school is going to be a great facility for this area. “The staff are also incredibly hard working and deserve a lot of praise. “I am assured that a number of snagging issues are in the process of being fixed and in the pool will be in use by February.” A council spokesman added: “Since the school opened we’ve received very positive feedback from staff, children, parents and the community on a fantastic new facility that’s helping to transform education for children and young people. “The hydrotherapy pool is in full working order and staff are currently being trained to make the best use of this central new feature. “Our contract also provides for snagging issues to be dealt with as and when required.”

title: borders-scouts-work-to-safeguard-the-future-of-golden-eagles
story: SCOUTS in Innerleithen have launched a new initiative to help safeguard the future of golden eagles in the UK.Working with the the South of Scotland Golden Eagle Project, the youngsters will become the countys first ever Golden Eagle Champions.The Innerleithen Scout Groups new role will allow the children to discover how golden eagles live and survive as well as learning from wildle experts as they get out and about in the countryside.It is also hoped that the initiative will further the Scouts knowledge of the local environment and the abundance of wildle on their doorstep.As part of their new role the children will also be designing a special badge that can be earned as part of their work.The population of golden eagles in the Borders has dropped in recent decades due to human activity and changes in land use, with between two and four pairs of the birds remaining in the south of Scotland.The South of Scotland Golden Eagle Project aims to reinforce this small, isolated and vulnerable population of the birds.Speaking on the launch of the initiative Philip Munro, Community Outreach Officer for the South of Scotland Golden Eagle Project said: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted to be working with the Scottish Borders Scouts, and their trailblazing Innerleithen Group, on the UKrsquos first ever Golden Eagle Champions initiative."The future of conservation depends on initiatives like this that encourage young people to get involved and make a dference. Their involvement will truly lead the way for other local Scout Groups and make a huge contribution to helping to safeguarding the future of this iconic species in the south of Scotland and beyond.Chris Kennedy, a volunteer with Scouts Scotland and currently leading their Innerleithen Scout Group, said: ldquoWe are really excited to be part of this incredible project to help protect Scotlandrsquos Golden Eagles. This is a fantastic opportunity for our Scouts to take a hands on approach, working together with other people across our community as well as some of the countryrsquos leading wildle and raptor experts on such a hugely important issue."The young people involved really will get a chance to impact on our natural heritage for generations to come, and is a real example of how Scouts can make a dference in the communities they live in.ldquoAnd the opportunity isnrsquot just for our young people our adult volunteers at our Innerleithen Group will also get the chance to be involved in the project sothis sounds like something you would like to help with then wersquod love to hear from you.Steve Backshall, Scouts Ambassador said: ldquoThis is an amazing opportunity for Scouts in the Scottish Borders to be a part of the South of Scotland Golden Eagle Project. They will be playing a vital role in the continued protection of many unique and important species, such as Scotlandrsquos golden eagles.Francesca Osowska, Scottish Natural Heritagersquos Chief Executive, said: ldquoCongratulations to Innerleithen Scout Group for being the UKrsquos first-ever Golden Eagle Champions! This is a wonderful programme, and Irsquom sure theyrsquoll love seeing and learning about these magnicent birds right in the Borders. Itrsquos fantastic to see the golden eagles doing so well in South Scotland, and wersquore thrilled to helpthem to places where they were once an important part of our wildle.

title: bbc-science-editor-to-visit-galashiels
story: Environmental journalist David Shukman is set to give a talk in Galashiels later this month.The BBC Science Editor will be taking to the stage to speak on the pros and cons of deep sea mining as part of the Royal Scottish Geographical SocietyrsquosInspiring People talks programme.The event, being held at Border Colleges Galashiels campus, will focus on the Deep Sea Gold Rush, the search for valuable minerals in the depths of the ocean.Over the course of his career, David has travelled the globe reporting on a range of topical news stories, visiting over  countries worldwide.Since joining the BBC in  as a TV news trainee, he has worked as a Defence Correspondent, Europe Correspondent, World Affairs Correspondent then finally Environment and Science Correspondent, a post hersquos held since .He is a familiar presence on the television and is known well known for his stories on climate change issues and the Polar regions.He was the first journalist to make a live television broadcast from Britainrsquos Antarctic base and has also travelled through the North West Passage and reported on sea level rises from Tuvalu as well as on plastic waste in the Pacic Ocean.Most recently, he has pioneered coverage of a brand new frontier in mining where the search has begun for valuable minerals in the deepest, darkest depths of the ocean.And the reason why companies are plunging so far down is simple: rocks on the sea floor are worth so much more to prospectors than those on land ndash they contain far more gold, copper, zinc and rare earth elements.But, as several dozen companies are on the brink of starting mines in the deep ocean, environmentalists have begun to raise concerns about damage to fragile marine ecosystems and the possible the extinction of rare le forms.Sir David Attenborough ndash a recipient of two of RSGSrsquo most distinguished Medals and who first spoke for the Society  years ago ndash was aghast when he heard that miners were targeting hydrothermal vents where le might have begun.Commenting on the upcoming talk, David Shukman said: ldquoAs a news reporter itrsquos always a pleasure to have the chance to discuss issues in greater depth and Irsquom hoping that my subject will provoke a lively debate."Few realise that wersquore on the brink of a new gold rush underwater and Irsquom looking forward to sharing my insights from as far afield as the Caribbean and Papua New Guinea.ldquoItrsquos also a great pleasure to be invited to speak in Galashiels as I have plenty of family connections in Scotland. Most notably, my mother lives near Lockerbie in a house originally bought by her uncle, the historian Sir Steven Runciman.Mike Robinson, Chief Executive of the RSGS said: ldquoDavidrsquos talk in Galashiels is set to be a lively one as he gets under the skin of this controversial topic and poses insightful questions ndash something he is known to do so well."During his time speaking for the RSGS in January, David will also be presented with Honorary Fellowship of the RSGS for his sustained work in the field of science communication."At a time where the media is more important than ever, the Society was keen to recognise his trusted voice on issues such as climate change and the environment.Commenting on this award, Mike added:ldquoDavid has been a champion of informed, impartial and intelligible information throughout his career with the BBC. We are therefore delighted to welcome David as an Honorary Fellow, joining a distinguished group of influential and inspiring people.As an Honorary Fellow, David will be added to a list including Sir Ernest Shackleton, Neil Armstrong, Sir Edmund Hilary, Mary Robinson, Annie Lennox and Karen Darke, as well as Davidrsquos fellow BBC film-makers Sir David Attenborough, Doug Allan and Gordon Buchanan.David will speak at the Scottish Borders Campus, Nether Road, Galashiels, TD HE on Tuesday January  at .pm.Ticketsare available via Eventbrite, via the RSGS website, or on the door. They are pound for visitors, pound for Tiso Outdoor Experience Card Holders, and FREE for RSGS Members, Students or Us.

title: nominations-open-for-st-ronans-principals
story: NOMINATIONS are now open for the  St Ronans Standard Bearer and Principal Guest.The Innerleithen festival takes place this year from July  through to July .St Ronanrsquos Border Games Committee began inviting nominations this week.Chairman Alan Patterson said: "We are now seeking nominations for candidates to lead the nd Anniversary of the Games.ldquoWe have been running the public nomination process for the last few years and we hope that the public will help the selection committees once again by nominating deserving people for these important positions."Nominations, which will close on Friday, March , should be made in writing to joint secretary, K.J.
