title: letters-if-theresa-may-can-change-her-mind-why-cant-the-rest-of-us
story: Anent democracy, we are constantly fed the line that to have a second vote on the subject of EU membership is undemocratic as we already voted decisively only two and a half years ago. But what of the right to change onersquos mind  Consider Theresa May herself. First, she supported Remain, but now doggedly supports Leave. Secondly, the law decreed a parliamentary election result was for five years, before people could change their minds. Mrs May, however, after two years, ignored that and called a snap election, hoping that voters would have changed their minds and give her a bigger majority. Now she insists that two years is far too soon to allow the electorate to change their minds. Perhaps goose and gander are relevant here.Anent ldquothe will of the people, a phrase that infuriates me every time I hear it, Irsquod like to ask ldquowhich people  Surely in a democracy, on a matter of such critical importance, ldquothe people are all adults who reside here, contribute to the economy by working, pay their taxes to fund services and will live with the result of the vote for the rest of their lives  That may be the normal electorate, but in the EU referendum several million EU spouses, family and long-term resident workers were deliberately removed from the eligible roll. A huge number have given years to this country, in some cases  to  years, and may live with the consequences of the vote for as long again. But they were not allowed to vote in the referendum, and now must register for permission to be second-class citizens.Furthermore, the Leave vote represented only . per cent of the electorate. The margin by which Leave won was very slightly less than that for devolution in , a margin which was considered too small to represent the will of the people. Let us not forget, too, the generation of young folk excluded, old enough to work, pay tax, get married and join the military, whose whole adult lives will be affected.The will of the people  Democratic  I think not. Let us remember ldquono taxation without representation and kill these lies stone dead.L McGregor,Gartcows Road, Falkirk.THE catastrophic handling of Brexit highlights to what extent our political process is now mired in the mud.Theresa May has suffered no fewer than  Commons defeats,  of them in connection with Brexit. In no previous era of British politics could such a calamitous prime minister have survived such a weight of defeats, including the humiliating historic loss she recently suffered over the Withdrawal Agreement.In the past, losing a vote of confidence on a key piece of legislation was considered sufficient to stand down. For example, having split his party over the Corn Laws in , Sir Robert Peel resigned as prime minister after the defeat of his Irish Coercion Bill. Gladstone was also forced to resign in , again after a defeat on the Irish issue.In terms of the modern era, four prime ministers resigned and four stepped down on alleged grounds of ill-health. Indeed, two quit office even after winning key votes because their margins of victory made them seem moral defeats. Neville Chamberlain resigned in May , despite having won the ision on the disastrous Norway campaign, and Margaret Thatcher famously resigned despite her victory over Michael Heseltine in the first round of a Tory leadership contest.Realising the game was up, even David Cameron resigned after losing the Brexit referendum.It is a damning indictment of Mrs May and her party that she can even contemplate staying in office. The French philosopher and diplomat, Joseph de Maistre famously said: ldquoIn a democracy people get the leaders they deserve. I disagree, we deserve so much better than this humiliating shambles.Alex Orr,Flat ,  Marchmont Road, Edinburgh.THOUGH Northern Ireland Secretary, Karen Bradley, is adamant that there is no link between the recent unrest in Derry and the Brexit process, she is guilty of underplaying the threat this poses to the short and long term security of the country she represents at Westminster .Our current Brexit impasse continues to distress many iniduals and communities throughout the UK and nowhere more so than Northern Ireland. The uncertainty that permeates our economic and political system at present, allied to the fact that the people of Northern Ireland have been without a devolved assembly at Stormont for more than two years, provides an opportune climate that dissident factions, such as the New IRA, will exploit for their own ends.Transport and postal services have been suspended to some Republican areas of Derry as fears of terrorist violence and disruption continue to grow. Mark Hamilton, Assistant Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland , views the current terrorist attacks as "the most signicant in recent years". Yet Ms Bradley would have us believe that the present political climate in the UK, with the possibility of a no- deal Brexit and therefore a hard border in Ireland, does not influence the recklessness of terrorists and their ability to drag Northern Ireland back to sectarian violence and chaos.A recent Amorach poll in the Irish republic found that  percent of people asked would fear ato violence in Ireland following Brexit. It is now more than  years since the Good Friday Agreement brought comparative stability to Northern Ireland, in which time there has been undoubted economic progress and changes in social,not political attitudes. The Troubles witnessed more than , deaths in Northern Ireland yet the passage of time seems to blind many politicians and parties of the appalling price in human lives that could be paidthere is no orderly and transparently clear plan for Britain exiting the EU.Neither the British nor the Irish Governments appear, even at this perilously late stage in proceedings, to possess a contingency plan in the event of a no-deal Brexit, a somewhat disconcerting,not downright alarming, state of affairs.I cannot help wondering how politicians and the press would view a similar situationtransplanted to the British mainland.Owen Kelly, Dunvegan Drive, Stirling.I ACKNOWLEDGE that passions run high over Brexit and that it is wise to have contingency plans in place, but are the dire predictions of widespread civil unrest and a breakdown of law and order in the event of a No-deal or a second referendum by senior politicians of dferent factions deliberately overstated and alarmist, and could they be counter-productive  R Russell Smith, Milton Road, Kilbirnie.Read more: Irish border backstop would constrain UK negotiating position

title: television-shouldnt-take-cold-feet-when-it-comes-to-older-characters
story: What  How can this be  More than one writer went on to suggest that its ftysomething characters no longer appeal because they are ageing, that viewers are tired of seeing them continue to face problems and puzzles that as thirtysomething were fun ndash but no longer.This suggests the lives of the -plus generation arenrsquot worthy of translation onto the screen. Which is nonsense. The wonderful existentialist crises that increases with age are all the more heightened when you have to factor in an ever-increasing awareness of mortality and moles, of strange lumps arriving in places they shouldnrsquot, of the breakdown of both meniscus and relationships. How can this not make good television To suggest older characters on TV donrsquot work is like saying a classic car is valueless because it doesnrsquot have a satnav. Age implies a better defined character, which suggests heightened comedic possibility. Look at how Still Game has mined this seam of opportunity so wondrously over nine series.Two Doors Down, the second major TV comedy success story to come out of Scotland in recent years, also tunes in brilliantly to middle-aged induced fragility. And BBC rsquos Mum, starring Lesley Manville and Peter Mullan was right on the money. .One of the best comedies around right now is The Kominsky Method, the Netflix series which this year won a Golden Globe, starring -year-old Michael Douglas and -year-old Alan Arkin.The age of the actors is important. James Nesbittis arguably better than hersquos ever been. The Kominsky Methodrsquos stars are exquisite. Closer to home, who can deny Elaine C. Smith, Alex Norton, Johnny Watson and Arabella Weirarenrsquot turning out the best performances of their careers Yes, film and television may grasp at the beauty and talent of youth in the form of Bodyguard Richard Madden or Killing Eversquos Jodie Comer but who can deny the real performances emerge from the more mature actor  Who can forget Brian Coxrsquos Troy appearance, in which his Agamemnon revealed Brad Pittrsquos achilles heal to be his inability to match Coxrsquos acting talent More recently, -year-old Richard E. Grant, who says hersquos ldquonever been nominated for anything is up for an Oscars Best Supporting Actor.Age offers experience, and with it hoped for improved performances in most aspects of le. In politics age should almost be a prerequisite. Tony Blair and David Cameron were both  years old when they became PM. And it showed. There is the occasional emergence of bright young genius this side of Pitt The Younger but for the most part politics screams out for the statesperson, the wide thinker, and generally those characteristics come with experience. Itrsquos easy to make the argument that the likes of Kenneth Clarke, Vince Cable and Barbara Castle became better politicians with age.Sport has now recognised the value of advancing years. Billie Jean King played competitive tennis until she was . Roger Federer may be out of the Australian Open but who would bet against the -year-old at Wimbledon this year. Or Serena winning another slam  The footballers who play on until they are  are great role models.Writers can truly find their voice as they approach the final third of their le. Raymond Chandler didnrsquot publish the Big Sleep until he was . George Eliot didnrsquot write her classic Middlemarch until she was . And the music arena  Mick and the Stones and Macca and Elton and Bonnie and Dolly are still going strong. But does this mean iniduals should adopt a Buzz Lightyear ndash ldquoTo infinity and beyond ndash approach to every aspect of their le  Not at all. If a driver, for example, reaches  with a teenage-like sneering disdain for the motoring laws of the land then such a personrsquos rights should be forfeited. And sometimes actors reach the point they canrsquot remember their lines and itrsquos time to head for the wings.But television has to reflect society. The number of pensioners in Scotland will hit . million by . And itrsquos not enough just to feed them up with the semolina that is reality shows such as Strictly because  cent of the same age group watch Game of Thrones, Young people are turning to tablets, to YouTube. TV needs the advertisers, which means it needs to screen programmes that grab the grey. Yes, itrsquos argued the frailties of older age are just that bit more mordant than the mishaps of youth. But donrsquot buy into that. The heartache and misery and crises you enjoyed before you become a fty-something can still produce fun in later years. And programmes such as Cold Feet still work because they reflect this.

title: likelihood-of-a-second-referendum-rising-sharply-says-economist-intelligence-unit
story: The forecasting group put the probability of another poll at %, up from % in a similar analysis less than a fortnight ago, and said it expects the Government to delay Britains exit.:Nicola Sturgeon accuses Theresa May of running scared after PM rules out indyrefAnd it predicted that the Prime Ministers "plan B" for Brexit will not be sufficient to secure parliamentary approval, and placed the chance of it succeeding at %.The EIU had previously said there was a % chance of Mrs May getting a version of her deal approved by Parliament eventually.It said a second poll would give popular legitimacy to the next course of action, be it adopting a version of Mrs Mays deal, leaving with no deal or stopping Brexit.The analysis also predicted a % probability for a soft Brexit option, a % chance of a general election and a % likelihood of a no deal outcome.Danielle Haralambous, UK analyst at the EIU, said Theresa Mays "plan B" for her Brexit deal is "unlikely to do much to revive it"."As before, a lot depends on how much the EU is willing to bend on the Irish backstop arrangement, and as before, the EU has made clear that it will not."With the deal unlikely to be revived, the Brexit options have narrowed, and in our view the probability of a second referendum being held to break the political deadlock has risen sharply."We still think that when it comes down it, Mrs May and her government are not prepared to run down the Article  clock and leave the EU without a withdrawal agreement and transition arrangements in place."She added: "We therefore expect the Government to request an extension that avoids a clf-edge situation, and in our view a second referendum is the most likely next step.:Letters: If Theresa May can change her mind, why cant the rest of us "The outcome of such a referendum will depend on how the options are phrased and how the vote is structured, and this will be the subject of a y parliamentary debate."One downside from this outcome is that delaying Brexit to hold a referendum that includes the possibility of a vote for no deal extends the period of economic uncertainty faced by businesses, weighing on activity in the near term."We are revising down our forecast for economic growth in the UK in , to .% from .% previously."

title: msp welcomes further action on period poverty
story: Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin has welcomed further funding to increase the number of places where free sanitary products are available.The announcement was made by Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell and means that between now and for the next financial year, a total of £million will be made available to local authorities, who will deliver the expansion.It will increase the roll-out of the Scottish Government’s world leading action and access beyond schools, colleges and universities.Local authorities will work in partnership with other organisations to meet local needs and increase availability.Ms Martin has been a campaigner for action on period poverty and providing free access to sanitary products including a resolution at SNP Party Conference in  calling for the introduction of an ‘S-card’.In , Aberdeen became the city chosen for a pilot project providing free sanitary products across several regeneration areas in the city.Commenting, Gillian Martin MSP said: “The Scottish Government has led the way with access to sanitary products in schools, colleges and universities.“It is excellent news that it will now go even further by increasing the number of places where these vital products are available which could help to reach more people on low incomes.“Period poverty is a real issue for many women who have to decide between feeding their family and purchasing sanitary products. Access to products should be a basic right afforded to everyone and I am pleased that an issue I’ve been incredibly passionate about will now be put in to practice supporting more girls and women.”Councillor Kelly Parry, COSLAs Community Wellbeing Spokesperson said: "COSLAwelcomes the wider roll-out of free sanitary provision across our communities. title: new waste strategy for aberdeenshire to be decided
story: Aberdeenshire Councilrsquos Infrastructure Services Committeewill discuss a new waste strategy after views were sought in a consultation in September on proposals to push up the arearsquos recycling rate and send less materials to landfill. Discussions on the future of the service were scheduled to take place in November but were delayed to allow extra time to take residentsrsquo views into account - proposed service changes have been amended as a result.Proposals to close the Insch Household Waste and Recycling Centrehave been removed as a result of public feedback. It is proposed that the centre would stay open two days a week, with the cost to be covered by slightly shortening opening hours at other recycling centres.Changes to kerbside services have also been proposed and, out of the two options consulted on, councillors are recommended to choose the option which will give residents a  litre non-recyclable waste bin to be emptied every three weeks. Paper card and metals, cartons and plastics recycling bins would also be incorporated into the -weekly collection cycle, together with a weekly food waste collection. Although a dferent option was more popular in the consultation, professional advice is that the alternative is most likely to encourage residents to recycle more and send less waste to landfill.By increasing recycling the proposed change is expected to reduce service costs by at least £, per year, money which will be reinvested into other essential council services.It is also proposed to double the number of seasonal garden waste collection points, with new facilities in locations including Balmedie, Kemnay, Kintore, Mintlaw, Newmachar and Oldmeldrum.Aberdeenshirersquos current recycling rate is only .%, but the services currently available to residents should allow over % of waste to be recycled.  Over half of the materials put into local non-recyclable waste bins are actually recyclable through existing services ndash equating to around , tonnes of recyclable materials being landfilled at a cost of £.million a year.Sending biodegradable waste to landfill will also be banned from . This includes non-recyclable household waste currently landfilled, so an alternative has to be found. Landfilling waste costs twice as much as recycling, so not only does maximising the value of a material benefit the environment, it also frees up money for other council services. title: workshop to develop artwork ideas for new kintore rail station
story: A day of workshops to develop ideas for potential future artwork at the new Kintore Rail Station will take place on Saturday .People living in the town and surrounding communities are invited to take part in the event, which will run from .am to .pm in Kintore Church Hall.Anyone who wants to be involved, but without taking part in the workshop sessions, is welcome to simply drop-in throughout the day.Studio Niro, a multidisciplinary design practice, is organising the event in collaboration with Aberdeenshire Council. The workshops will involve colour mixing and print making to create a library of Kintore colours and shapes which will then be used to develop artwork.The sessions will take place from .am-pm and from -.pm and members of the community are asked to bring along a camera and any old photos of Kintore they may have. Free tickets can be booked at www.krsartwork.eventbrite or by calling   . The new railway station is part of the wider Aberdeen to Inverness Improvement Project .A representative from Network Rail will be available during the day to provide information on the project and forthcoming related works in .The workshops also provide the opportunity to re-unite for the first time in at least fty years two benches installed at the original Kintore Station, which was closed in the late s.Prior to their restoration, both benches will be on display for members of public to see. title: Burns treat for seniors
story: SENIOR citizens are being invited to join Thurso Town Improvements Associationto celebrate Scotlands national poet.TTIA volunteers say they are refreshed after a busy festive season, having waved farewell to Santa and his elves for another year.Their efforts have now turned to celebrating the birthday of Robert Burns and the senior citizens of Thurso are being asked to go along to a free supper complete with live music, Highland dancing and poetry recitals.It will take place on Thursday, January , from .pm, in the Royal British Legion club and will see many familiar faces take to the stage in an evening of traditional Burns entertainment.TTIA committee members are keen to thank Castletown Butchers, the Corner Store at  and the Legion catering team for their sponsorship of the event which allows them to offer free tickets to senior citizens in the town. The TTIA team will dust off their aprons and act as hosts and waiting staff for the evening and are looking forward to welcoming everyone.Should any member of the public wish to join TTIA in a voluntary role for the evening, they are encouraged to email the association thursotownimprovements@gmail or search on Facebook to make contact.Tickets are available now from the Kiln Store in Thurso. Due to the popularity of the event, tickets are limited to two per person.Those planning to attend are asked to make the Kiln Store team awarethey have any special dietary requirements when collecting tickets. A limited amount of vegetarian and gluten-free haggis will be available on the night.New volunteers always welcome at TTIA.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Caithness battered by gale force winds
story: GALE-force winds battered Caithness on Monday, leaving a trail of destruction across the county.Police advised all drivers in the area to take extra caution following a yellow weather warning issued by the Met Office but ious incidents were reported throughout the day.A mile south of Wick on the A, a Sams Furniture van heading south left the road and overturned into a field.A police spokesman said the van was the only vehicle involved in the incident and "the owner had arranged recovery". No serious injuries were reported.Further south at Berriedale a similar incident occurred at .pm when a lorry went off the A. The police spokesman confirmed that the road was cleared very quickly and again there were "no apparent serious injuries".Those heading further south were delayed by closures on the Dornoch and Kessock bridges due to the "exceptionally high wind gusts".The Met Office issue further warnings that parts of Scotland will be battered by gale-force winds.Chief Inspector Stewart Mackie, from Police Scotlands road policing ision, said: "Police Scotland is advising all drivers to travel with extra caution and ensure you and your vehicle are adequately prepared for the conditions making sure you have sufficient fuel and supplies such as warm clothing, food and water in the event you are delayed for several hours. Charge your mobile phone and plan your route as well as alternative routes."Whipped up by the high winds a huge sandstorm blew from Thurso Beach into the towns neighbouring streets.Gardens, pavements, drains and cars were affected by the sand and pedestrians claimed to be "temporarily blinded" by the storm.Thurso and North West Caithness councillor Matthew Reiss said he had "never seen the likes" of the massive sandstorm around the Esplanade.A woman who lived in the affected area said she had "never ever seen sand come off the beach in the  odd years" she had lived there.On Monday afternoon Mr Reiss said: "The council will be in attendance tomorrow morning to bulldoze the sand off the pavements and roads, clear drains and generally tidy up. Unfortunately sand will damage locks, window mechanisms, vehicles and grass."The councillor went on to advise people to try to wash the sand off all surfaces and said senior council officials from the roads department and the flood team will also be investigating."The longer term and very serious question is what is causing the level of our beach to rise so quickly in recent months " he added.Pennyland Primary School was closed for the afternoon as the winds began to rise. The roof of a McColls store in the Mount Pleasant area blew off but nobody was reported to be injured.The Dounreay nuclear site was officially closed at pm. All  staff were evacuated after winds battered the area for a couple of hours.A spokeswoman for Dounreay Site Restoration said "the safety of staff was paramount".Wicks weather watcher Keith Banks said on Monday: "There have been gusts in the hurricane force  category. Strongest gust so far in Wick today has been mph. A severe gale force  west north westerly has been blasting Wick since noon."Chief Inspector Stewart Mackie said: "If you are driving a vehicle which may be vulnerable to being blown over in such conditions along exposed routes including bridges, please exercise additional caution and plan your route to avoid exposed areas or consider cancelling your journey until conditions improve."Previous incidents have clearly shown the dangers of driving such vehicles and the subsequent danger created for other road users, emergency services and recovery operatives where incidents have occurred due to drivers ignoring warnings."Winter driving is a question of common sense and all drivers should ask themselvesthey really need to travel when conditions are poor."No-one should ever place themselves at risk on the road and it may be worth making alternative arrangements such as delaying travel until conditions improve or using public transport."Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: One last goodnight from him and him
story: A CAITHNESS radio show which has been broadcast for  years comes to an end on Thursday night.The last Jim and Ali Show ndash a mixture of rock, blues, country and a bit of crack ndash goes out on the local community radio station Caithness FM at pm tomorrow.Jim Labor and Ali Murray have been presenting the show since  but are about to hang up their mikes.Jim first arrived with the American Navy in the s while Ali came to the far north in the s.Almost immediately they built up a strong partnership on the then new local radio station and they have held the seven to nine slot on Thursday nights for  years.Jim said: "Were really sad that we have to leave as its been a breeze and we both love doing the show."But we wanted to take this opportunity to publicly acknowledge our gratitude to everyone that has listened to us over the last two decades, including our secret characters."The characters on the show are real people who live in Caithness and who have been allotted nicknames which are regularly discussed live on air.They have never been named apart from a select few, while over the years regular Jim and Ali listeners have become accustomed to an eclectic mix of music that has ranged from country and western to heavy rock with everything in between.Ali added: "After such a long time its painful to depart, but we do want to say a massive thanks again to everyone who has tuned in along the way. And we really hope that radio as a medium flourishes in Caithness with future listeners accessing and interacting with the programmes they deserve."Soyouve never heard the show before then you have only one last chance to do so.Just before nine oclock tomorrow night the words "so its goodnight from me, and its good night from me. Cue the Captain Scarlet theme tune," will be heard for the last time.The idea of community radio in Caithness came about as a result of a chance conversation between then local MP Robert Maclennan and Thomas Prag, managing director of Moray Firth Radio, in .Public meetings were held to gauge interest and the reaction was positive so the idea took off. The following autumn links were formed with Moray Firth Radio and a restricted service licence was applied for to enable a temporary broadcast in the area.In October , the first broadcast took place. The station was based in a portable building in the garden of a local councillors house. Caithness community radio took to the airwaves for the first time. The rest, as they say, is history.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Silence on A9 scheme
story: A HIGHLANDS and Islands MSP is putting pressure on the Scottish Government to confirm a start date for the pound million Berriedale Braes road scheme.Labours Rhoda Grant says she wants to know when the improvement project will get under way after what she describes as "years of pushing transport secretaries to get moving" on it.Mrs Grant has lodged a parliamentary question asking about a starting date and the available funding, claiming there has been a "deathly silence" on what has happened to the scheme.She said former transport secretary Derek Mackay had made it plain in a reply in  that the Scottish Government "must await suitable funding becoming available to progress it further".In  the then transport secretary, Humza Yousaf, published made orders for the project "as a clear commitment to deliver the scheme". Then, last February, Transport Scotland, the Scottish Governments transport agency, said "construction or planned improvements to the challenging hairpin bend" were expected to start in . Four companies were invited to bid for the project.However, in August the agency said it could not give a firm timescale for construction but suggested it could be after Easter or May .Mrs Grant said: "The public should be given a definite date instead of this shilly-shallying which has taken place over many years."A spokesman for Transport Scotland said: "The tender competition for the A Berriedale Braes improvement scheme has now concluded and is currently in the mandatory standstill period. Construction work is expected to commence in the new year in line with the successful contractors programme."Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Sir Chris top peak is Suilven
story: HE has conquered Everest and is considered Britains greatest living mountaineer.But climbing luminary Sir Chris Bonington has told top travel guide Wanderlust that Suilven in north-west Sutherland is the mountain that most shaped his le.Sir Chriss career has included  expeditions to the Himalayas, including four to the worlds highest mountain, and the first ascent of the south face of Annapurna.The mountain was immortalised last year in the film Edie, in which Sheila Hancock stars as an octogenarian who makes a le-changing decision to climb its steep, remote slopes.Sir Chrissaid: "Suilven is a long whale-back of a mountain, but when you approach it from the west you just see the end of it ndash an absolutely perfect peak, with a great sandstone buttress."I first climbed Suilven when I was  and it is one of the most magical days I have ever had."It was my second holiday in Scotland, just after I had discovered climbing, and I went up with a friend. We carried our rucksacks, hitch-hiked, and bivvied most of the time. I remember sleeping in the ruins of Ardvreck Castle ndash it was the only thing with a roof on it for miles ndash before we set off from Lochinver to climb Suilven."We tried following a route which wasnt very good, so we ended up climbing a new route."The views from the top of Suilven were incredible. To the south there was a big, wide loch, dotted with islands."That day captured everything that I love about climbing and inspired me to keep doing it ndash the sense of exploration, the beauty of the mountains themselves, as well as the experience of really stretching yourself in the process."Second on his list was the North Face of the Eiger, ahead of the Central Tower of Paine, Chile.The Old Man of Hoy, Orkneys ft sea-stack, was placed fourth on his list. Sir Chris made the first ascent of the Old Man of Hoy in  and climbed it again in ."I was the first person to climb the Old Man of Hoy and the oldest when I climbed it again when I was ," Sir Chris said.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Towns ring in the new year
story: THE two Caithness towns brought in  in very dferent ways, with Thurso hosting a musical street party which saw more than  braving the stormy conditions while Wick had a more sedate affair with its annual bonfire at Bignold Park and about  hardy souls gathering together to take in the bells.Tracey Taylor, chairwoman of Hogmanay in Thurso, said: "We were really pleased with the event and everyone seemed to enjoy themselves. The weather meant there wasnt as big a crowd as previous years but that didnt dampen peoples spirits."The wind and rain took its toll on the numbers as usually some  descend on Sir Johns Square for the bells. Nevertheless, well over  party-goers turned out to sing along with local band CoverCover who played popular hits such as the Proclaimers Im Gonna Be .Thursos Santa Claus decoration in the square looked a bit worse for wear as it fell to the ground in the high winds, with one reveller joking that "hed had too much mulled wine".Santa wasnt the only casualty and a few wreaths from the base of the Victory war memorial were blown away as well.Tracey added: "Well be holding an AGM soon and details of this will go on Facebook page for anyone interested in being a part of future events."Wed like to thank all those who volunteered, helping with the litter pick at the end, and the sponsors, as well as everyone who attended."In Wick, the heat was on as  revellers braved the wind and gathered around the annual bonfire at the top of Bignold Park.Under the guidance of local man Iain Sutherland ndash who revived the tradition over  years ago with friend Mackie MacDonald after the council had given up on it ndash a ft high conglomeration of discarded Christmas trees, wooden pallets and compressed paper had been built earlier that same day.Looking down from a safe vantage point in his daughter Helens car, Iain said he was proud and "delighted" as he watched the bonfire take hold.His son-in-law Mervyn Hill, who runs the Netherclfe Hotel with Helen, had not only learned the fine art of fire-building but had organised for some members of the towns pipe band to bring in  with Hogmanay tunes."Its been a successful night and despite the wind we had around  people show up," said Mervyn."We had people of all ages here. It was a good family event and everything went really well."Mervyn explained how his father-in-law had shown him techniques to make the blaze take hold by building around a central core of compressed paper and cardboard. "You need to make a tunnel into the centre. Then you light a box, push it in and away she goes. The wind blows through the pallets and eggs it on too."Mervyn said that the help of local contractors, builders and volunteers helped keep the tradition going.Long after the public had left as the rain came on at around .am, Mervyn was still busy tending to the fire with a sturdy rake in his hand."Ill keep an eye on it through the night and make sure its under control," he said. "Ill rake up what I can and come back when its cooled down to pick up any nails that people or their pets could get injured by."* See this weeks John OGroat Journal for more Hogmanay pictures.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeThursday  Jan  : AM

title: invitation to tender issued for northern isles ferry contract
story: An Invitation to Tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services has been issued to three bidders, the Scottish Government announced today, Thursday.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July.The contract is estimated to be worth £m and will run for eight years. The names of the companies involved have however, not been released.Minister for energy, connectivity and the islands, Paul Wheelhouse, said: “Issuing the Invitation to Tender marks the next stage of the process to award the new contract to operate the Northern Isles Ferry Services.“The contract will run for eight years, allowing us to build a strong working relationship with the successful bidder, and all the routes within the network are being tendered as a single bundle.“The Scottish Government remains fully committed to high quality ferry services to the Northern Isles. A key benefit of this new contract is the in-built flexibility, allowing the ferry services to be amended to reflect future changes in demand across the important sectors of the islands’ economies – tourism, fishing, food and drink, aquaculture and farming. Scottish Ministers will also retain control of all of important issues, such as fares and timetables, through the public service contract.“We are committed to a fair, open and transparent tender which aims to get the best possible deal for the communities that depend on these ferry services.”• Commenting on the issue, Northern Isles MSP’s Liam McArthur and Tavish Scott said: “The Scottish Government have finally issued the tender. The timescale is very tight indeed given the operator needs to be up and running the North Isles leline ferry services in  months’ time. It is essential that companies make constructive bids with improvements to the existing service. It must, in particular, recognise the growing freight volumes that are being exported south to the Scottish mainland.“So the tender bids must be properly assessed to ensure the service moves forward and not backwards. And the endless saga of RET must come to an end, otherwise how can bidding companies submit a proposed fare policy ”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: oic makes urgent call for ferry funding
story: Orkney Islands Council is again calling on the Scottish Government to honour a commitment to provide fully fair funding for the county’s inter-island ferry service — or it will hand the service back to the government to run.The council is warning it cannot afford to run the service during the year ahead unless the government covers the full cost involved — this amounts to £. million. OIC Leader James Stockan has notied Ministers that the council will hand over responsibility for running the service to Transport Scotland, unless sufficient funding is provided.A year ago, a similar level of support was secured, after a y campaign by OIC for fair funding. Of this, £. million was allocated to fully fund Orkney’s internal ferry service during the current financial year, with £ million awarded to Shetland Islands Council for its ferry operations.“But this time there is no specic amount allocated to Orkney or Shetland. The government recognises that it will cost £. million to operate our ageing fleet of ferries during - — and that is what we are asking the government to provide.”OIC is also looking to the government to fund the replacement of the current inter-island fleet. The council has been working with the government on this for a number of years and is currently developing a business case setting out the service levels local communities require, and the engineering options needed to achieve these.Councillor Stockan added: “We would object in the strongest possible termswe end up with a reduction in our ferries funding. This would place a wholly disproportionate and unfair burden on the smallest council in Scotland and would mean us having to make cuts to other vital services.“The ferries are a leline for remote and fragile communities across our islands. Orkney has the oldest fleet and the highest fares in the country — an inequality we cannot address without proper financial support from the Scottish Government.We are calling on the government to take an honourable approach to fulfilling the will of the Scottish Parliament that we should receive fair and equitable funding for our inter-island ferry service. The principle of transferring Orkney’s internal ferry service to the Scottish Government, at no net detriment to OIC, has already been approved by the council. That is a route we will have to take unless we are provided with the funds to run the service over the year ahead.”For the full story, pick up a copy of The Orcadian, this Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: rural secretary agrees to to look again at options for orkney abattoir
story: The Scottish Government#s rural economy secretary, Fergus Ewing, has agreed to look again at potential option for securing a locally-based abattoir in Orkney.Mr Ewing confirmed that he and his officials would re-engage with Orkney Islands Council, the local branch of the NFUS, Orkney Auction Mart and other stakeholders after Orkney MSP Liam McArthur raised the issue recently — first during ministerial question time in Scottish Parliament yesterday afternoon and then directly with Mr Ewing.During yesterday#s exchange on the importance of local food and drink, Mr McArthur took the opportunity of again highlighting the impact that the abattoir’s closure would have on the promotion of Orkney beef and lamb. In response, rural affairs minister Mairi Gougeon accepted that Orkney beef and lamb is not only important to the food and drink sector in the islands, but for Scotland as a whole. She agreed to look at ways the Scottish Government may be able to help in identying potential options.Commenting after these exchanges, Mr McArthur said: “It remains a concern that Orkney continues to be without a local abattoir. I am very conscious that the longer this remains the case, the more dficult it will be to find a solution.“I welcome the cabinet secretary’s willingness to re-engage with the Council and other local stakeholders in Orkney in an attempt to make sure that all possible options are fully explored. Mr Ewing acknowledged the importance of the Orkney beef and lamb brands not just to the islands’ but Scotland’s food and drink sector. I hope, even at this late stage, that a solution can be found.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Conon Bridge school travel plan set for an upgrade
story: PARENTS of children in a village that has witnessed a surge in housebuilding are being asked to have their say on a new school travel plan.The appeal centres on Ben Wyvis Primary in Conon Bridge. A survey has been issued seeking information on issues such as what factors influence parentsrsquo decisions on whether to let their children walk or cycle to school and how much they value safer crossings, vehicle speed-reduction measures and improved road safety education as well as information on the benefits of walking and cycling.The survey includes questions about the distance pupils attending Ben Wyvis Primary live from the school and the modes of transport they use to get there.It also seeks views on measures that could reduce congestion at the school gate. These include involvement in voluntary cycle training and a car sharing scheme.Itrsquos part of a wider effort across the Highlands to work on safer routes to school, reduce unnecessary car use and encourage healthier alternatives where possible, such as walking and cycling.The survey, supported by the parent council, can be found online and completed at www.surveymonkey r BenWyvisPSThursday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross filmmaker turned author gets to art of matter in new novel
story: Tain-based Mike Herd had plenty of time to ponder plots when he worked as a cameraman on more than  films, many requiring endless patience to capture unforgettable footage.His latest novel, The Medusa Shield, is a ldquomystical fantasy set in the fictitious village of Rockburn on the eastern seaboard of the Black Isle. Set in , it sees protagonist Scott and his father James take the car ferry across the Beauly Firth to Inverness as they watch men working on the Kessock Bridge.Scott agrees to attend a farm roup with his father and feels he is being watched by a yellow eye from a dirty painting hanging amongst the lots. Unknown to his father, he successfully bids for it and his le starts to alter in remarkable ways.The action swings between Aberdeen and Florence as Scott embarks on a journey of discovery.Mr Herd, who describes himself as ldquo going on , said time spent alone working on so many films served him.He said: ldquoBy the nature of film work there wasnrsquot a typical day because all trips y. The most memorable film that I have worked on must be Swamp Tigers in the Bangladeshi Sundarbans.ldquoUsing a converted river ferry boat as a mobile base, a typical day would be, rising at four and travelling in the dark to a hide built on stilts embedded in a channel.ldquoI would stay there on my own usually for twelve hours and I did that for months. Being in a hide that long gives you plenty of time to think.ldquoLying awake in bed in the morning, plot ideas and characters nag at me and I have to get up to write about them.ldquoI am a hopeless two-fingered typist which is very frustrating because they canrsquot keep up with whatrsquos going through my head. That aside It does surprise me how easy it is for me to write, I donrsquot know where that comes from. I try to write at least a thousand words a day but quite often Irsquoll hit a brick wall.ldquoI donrsquot worry about that because I know that I will get the inspiration to carry on later.ldquoI try to write about what I know, itrsquos much more convincing and I use locations Irsquove been to. title: Evanton dementia project is given time for more work
story: A WOODLAND-based project that has helped support dementia sufferers and their careers has been extended to take in the next few weeks.Funding has been won so that Evanton Community Wood can run an eight week course which started lastFriday.It will involve a programme of storytelling and crafting activities aimed at those with early onset dementia, and their carers.It is a continuation of the series of engaging and fun sessions managed by Evanton Wood last summer which were hailed as being very helpful to people with this condition. The programme starting today will culminate with ldquomemory blankets that each participant will design and create.Evanton Wood education co-ordinator Simon Harry said: ldquoThis is a great addition to our summer dementia programme as we have secured funding to continue this programme of activities in the woods throughout the early part of this year.ldquoThe work will be focused at Evanton Community Woods utilising the woodland cabin as a base and using the surrounding forest environment to help bring to le the memories and ideas of the group.ldquoWe will be working closely with local artist Lizzie McDougal who has been a big hit with our group.He added: ldquoLizzie will lead the sessions with input from Evanton Wood staff and volunteers.ldquoThe process will start with two storytelling sessions in which Lizzie will encourage the sharing of memories and stories from each couple within the group. Lizzie and the group will then create sketches from these conversations to use as prompts for the group to aid their design of the memory blanket.The programme is supported by the UK-wide DEEP project , and the blankets will be used at a DEEP gathering to be run at Evanton Woods in the spring. This gathering will be a celebration of all the positive outcomes that those with dementia in the Highlands have achieved.The Evanton Wood programme will run each Friday from .am - pm at the woodland cabin which is a short walk from the top of Chapel Road.Those attending should follow the signs into the wood, and lunch is included.For more information about the activities on offer in Evanton Wood please contact Simon Harry on  or email simon.harry@forest-educationThursday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Fresh deal is a sign of our intent says firm at Invergordon port
story: A MAJOR engineering firmrsquos decision to extend its contract at the Port of Cromarty Firth is a sign of its ldquocommitment to the area and wider UK market, its operations manager has said,Offshore project and engineering company Semco Maritimersquos decision to extend its use of the portrsquos Queens Dock facility follows its busiest ever year.In  ious vessels stayed in Queens Dock along with Maersk Reacher, which received reactivation upgrades over  months, and Maersk Innovator, which spent two months on site for the upgrade and installation of a cantilever extension.In the five years it has operated at the site Semco Maritime has carried out works on drilling rigs, pipe lay vessels, accommodation rigs, survey vessels, cargo boats and ious other projects, and has hosted numerous rigs.ldquoThe extension of our existing contract for Queens Dock shows Semco Maritimersquos commitment to maintain and strengthen our presence in the UK, said Neil Robertson, operations manager at Semco Maritime, Invergordon.ldquoWe have seen our department in Invergordon flourish and deliver great service to our clients, not least thanks to a productive agreement with Port of Cromarty Firth with both parties fully behind repairs, upgrades and maintenance projects,The firm described Invergordon as a perfect base for ious offshore service projects, which had made it possible to carry out repairs, upgrades and maintenance for rigs in operation as far away as Malaysia, Australia and the Gulf of Mexico.Bob Buskie, chief executive of the Port of Cromarty Firth said Semco Maritimersquos presence ldquohas made Invergordon an attractive port for drilling contractors and subsea operators undertaking inspection, repair and maintenance projects.Thursday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland arts venue has strategy to combat fund gap
story: THE regionrsquos biggest arts venue has outlined how it must become more financially resilient.In its latest accounts, Eden Court in Inverness reported increased income and more expenditure in the year ending March ,  compared to the previous  months.Last year Eden Court lost pound, a year of funding ndashpound, from Creative Scotland and pound, from the Highland Council.A trusteesrsquo report the figures stated: ldquoThe principal risks identied are financial ones, particularly the effect of this yearrsquos signicant reduction in public funding.ldquoThe organisation must become more financially resilient by growing sources of earned income and building a safe level of reserves.ldquoAs public funding declines, the targets for earnings from trading activities necessarily increase, and the risk that these targets cannot be met also increases. At the same time, our cost base is likely to increase owing to inflationary pressures on resources.ldquoThis year we are working on a strategy for trading through our funding gap, increasing income from charitable trading, reducing costs wherever possible and developing partnerships to share services.ldquoAttention has also been focused on non-financial risks arising from the loss of some channels of regular communication with our major funders our relationship with both Creative Scotland and the Highland Council has been strengthened during the year to March ,  and subsequently.ldquoThe development of positive relationships with funders ndash public organisations and inidual philanthropists ndash remains a high priority and is a central part of Eden Courtrsquos financial strategy for the coming three years.Total income increased from pound,, in  to pound,, last year. For the same period, total expenditure moved from pound,, to pound,,.Total funds also went up from pound,, to pound,,.Advance ticket sales mean that Eden Courtrsquos cash flow position remains strong.The biggest event of the year was the Snow White panto, which sold more than , tickets for its  performances.The report stated: ldquoAttendance for the year has been unprecedented with audiences of , for live performances and , at film screenings. title: Life saving Ross shire Womens Aid centre issues action plan after mixed report
story: The Dingwall-based Ross-shire Womenrsquos Aid centre has received a mixed inspection report from the Care Commission watchdog.While the quality of care and support provided to abused women and their children was judged good, the quality of management and leadership was rated ldquoadequate.One woman told inspectors that the service was a le-saver and she wished it would receive more funding.However there were times when staff felt inadequately supported by management, said the report following the unannounced inspection. The report stated: ldquoSince our last inspection there had been changes within the management team and this had impacted on the overall quality of service provision.ldquoThe service provider acknowledged this was an area that they were under-performing in and as a result, an interim management team had recently been put in place. We met with the interim management team and noted that good progress was being made to address many areas we identied as needing improvement. We were also provided with a detailed action plan which identied immediate and future areas for improvement.ldquoAs a result of our findings we concluded that the service was currently operating to an adequate standard. Should we have found that the recent management team were not making signicant in-roads to address our concerns we would have graded the management and leadership as weak.ldquoWhen we spoke with staff, all said that they had been faced with many challenges and that there were times when they felt totally unsupported by management.It said staff continued to work in a dedicated and caring way, were well trained and experienced.It added: ldquoHowever, we were also aware that staff had been faced with a challenging time due to changes in the management of the service. This had clearly impacted on staff morale and a feeling of being unsupported at times. We have highlighted this as an area that needs to be improved on in the management and leadership theme in this report.Eight women who responded to the inspection questionnaires were happy overall with the quality of care and support provided.During the inspection comments noted included: ldquoThe service from Womenrsquos Aid is a le-saver ldquoMy care worker has supported me through the worst and shown me how far I have come, and ldquoI just wish they could get more funding so they can continue to provide this le-saving service.Thursday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Lochcarron cafe aims to cash in on success of NC500
story: A WESTER Ross communityrsquos bid to take advantage of its presence on a world-renowned visitor route and provide fresh opportunities for local people has received a pound, boost.Lochcarron Community Development Company is behind plans to redevelop an underused building at their existing community hub.It has won a pound, award from the The Princersquos Countryside Fund to support the redevelopment at the Smithy Community Hub, which provides workspaces for local craftsmen, a tourism information point and a community treehouse.The group now plan to turn a building on the site into a community cafeacute and shop, selling produce from local crofters and craft workers.The eco-friendly project will include a recycling point and facilities to charge electric cars, regarded as vital given the hubrsquos location on the busy North Coast  route.The building work is expected to take four months, and the fund has committed to support the salary of a project officer for a further year-and-a-half.Kristine MacKenzie, development officer at Lochcarron Community Development Company, said: ldquoOur vision for the Smithy Community Hub is to deliver economic, social and environmental benefits to a level capable of making a dference for local people and provide an enhanced experience for visitors.ldquoInformed by local circumstance and need, the underutilised community building will be refurbished and extended to accommodate a deli selling local produce, a craft outlet, a cafeacute and community learning space.ldquoOverall, the project will help tackle inequality, increase social interaction and reduce isolation, help address the current skills and employment gap, the high level of outward migration of young and replace some of the services recently lost. Recharging the community spirit will lead to a more sustainable future.She said funding from the Princersquos Countryside Fund would assist with training, the purchase of equipment needed to establish the produce outlet and help pay for a project officer.The result of additional funding bids will be known in the coming weeks.Claire Saunders, director of The Princersquos Countryside Fund, said: ldquoRural communities across the UK suffer from a loss of amenities such as shops and places to socialise, and this is felt even more keenly in remote areas such as the Scottish Highlands. Wersquore delighted to be supporting the Smithy Community Hub and look forward to working with them.The Princersquos Countryside Fund was established by The Prince of Wales in  with the aim of enhancing the prospects of family farm businesses and the quality of rural le. It sees the countryside ldquoas our most valuable natural asset and states that ldquoits contribution to our everyday le cannot be underestimated.The Princersquos Countryside Fund is open for grant applications until February . story: THE North Coast  is set to star on TV screens across the globe this week notndash when The Grand Tourrsquos new series hits Amazon Primersquos streaming service.The blockbuster driving show hosted by former Top Gear trio Jeremy Clarkson, Richard Hammond and James May s to screens on Friday.The show, which costs a reputed pound. million per episode to produce, is the most expensive series ever made by Amazon Prime and is one of its biggest hits, attracting legions of viewers.And the -mile circuit of the North Coast  will feature in the new run after the trio were filmed during their travels round it last spring.Indeed, the route is likely to be one of the highlights of the new series ndash after a segment of the trio driving across the Kylesku Bridge in an Alfa Romeo GTV, Lancia Gamma Coupe and a Fiat X featured prominently in the trailer.Plenty of other Inverness-shire, Ross-shire, Sutherland and Caithness locations are also expected to feature, with Tain, Invergordon, Inverness and Golspie among the numerous locations where people spotting the trio filming segments for the show.The latterrsquos Littleferry race track is also expected to feature at some point too.Business figures are predicting a boost to the North Coast rsquos global profile as a result of its appearance in the lastest series.Speaking during the triorsquos visit last spring, David Richardson, a development manager at the Federation of Small Businesses Highland, said: ldquoIt will attract more interest in the Highlands as a whole and businesses will be quick to take advantage of this and give tourists the best possible experience.Thursday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Support blooms for Invergordon garden project
story: A BID to save an under-threat gardening project for learning disabled adults in Easter Ross has won public support amid growing efforts to secure its long-term future.NHS Highland has withdrawn its funding for the initiative at the Isobel Rhind Centre in Invergordon, saying it cannot afford it.But at least , people have signed a petition backing the initiative and more than pound of a pound, target to fund a six-month extension has been raised thanks to the support of well-wishers responding to a crowdfunding drive set up by Cromarty Firth councillor Maxine Smith.A local businessman has also promised to match fund whatever is raised through the drive.Cllr Smith said thateveryone who signed the petition chipped in just pound, it would ensure a breathing space for the  users who have helped brighten up Invergordon with hanging baskets.Efforts to find a new model to deliver the scheme have been going on behind the scenes and NHS Highland has said that although funding will stop, the land at the centre can continue to be used. However, health chiefs have been accused of dragging their feet over helping to find a sustainable future model to deliver the scheme, which many of the users have said gives them a reason to get up in the morning.The project leader, who is employed by High Le Highland, has been told funding will end this month. According to Cllr Smith, garden users are ldquodevastated but adamant they wish to continue.She wants to see NHS Highland play a full role plotting the way forward, including carrying out self-directed supportassessments, a tool that aims to ensure people who are eligible for support are given the choice and control over how their inidual budget is arranged and delivered to meet their agreed health and social care outcomes.Tain-based Mike Herd, whose son has happily attended the scheme in Invergordon, said: ldquoNHS Highland made a commitment to me last year that they would try to help the garden project continue through a dferent funding formula. However, the reality is that letters asking for SDS funding have been ignored. It seems that NHS Highland have just abandoned the gardeners to a bleak futurelong-term funding cannot be agreed.Cllr Smith added: ldquoI make a plea, especially to big businesses locally, to contact me and offer some funding towards this worthwhile project that gives the adult users with learning disabilities pride and a reason to get up in the morning.ldquoIt is only a one-off payment I am seeking, not continual funding.NHS Highlandrsquos head of service for learning disabilities and autism, Arlene Johnstone, said: ldquoDue to financial pressures NHS Highland is no longer able to contribute funding to the Garden Project in Invergordon. However, we are supporting Councillor Maxine Smith in her efforts to find a new funding model and we have offered that,successful, they can continue to use the land in the grounds of the Isobel Rhind Centre. We have also introduced her to colleagues who have been able to advise of potential ways forward.ldquoNHS Highland is committed to ensuring that people with a learning disability can participate fully in our communities and therefore are also in discussion with High Le Highland and Councillor Maxine Smith to explore alternative ways of providing the activity that people enjoy.
